A variety of new [[National Hot Rod Association#Safety|safety]] rules were implemented following the conclusion of the investigation of the [[Scott Kalitta]] death in 2008. The NHRA had planned on returning Top Fuel and Funny Car classes to {{convert|1320|ft|m|abbr=on}} distances; however, racing in those classes remained at {{convert|1000|ft|m|abbr=on}} distance to contain costs with the United States economy still in recession, as well as to address ongoing safety concerns. There were 23 Top Fuel, Funny Car, and Pro Stock car events, and 17 Pro Stock Motorcycle events. ==Schedule== With the closure of the Memphis Motorsports Park as of 30 October 2009,{{cite web | url=http://www.dovermotorsports.com/track/press/article.php?dir=200910&id=3283 | title= DOVER MOTORSPORTS, INC. ANNOUNCES CLOSING OF MEMPHIS MOTORSPORTS PARK AND REALIGNMENT OF RACING DATES (press release) | date=2009-10-30 | accessdate = 2009-10-31}} the Full Throttle Series is now slated for 23 events:{{cite web| url= http://www.nhra.com/schedules/2010fts.aspx| title= 2010 NHRA Full Throttle Drag Racing Series schedule| accessdate= 2009-11-01| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091210163117/http://www.nhra.com/schedules/2010fts.aspx| archivedate= 2009-12-10| deadurl= yes| df= }} The Virginia NHRA Nationals has also been eliminated, as Virginia Motorsports Park chose to align with rival [[Kenneth Feld]]'s [[International Hot Rod Association]] instead (many tracks changed sanctioning, owing to their sportsman classes). After 47 years as a driver and owner, [[Don Prudhomme]] announced his retirement from the series.{{cite news|url=http://www.dovermotorsports.com/track/press/article.php?dir=200910&id=3283|title=Prudhomme announces retirement from drag racing|date=2010-01-07|accessdate=2010-02-22|work=nhra.com|publisher=[[National Hot Rod Association]]}} Funny car driver [[Mike Neff]] stepped down as driver to become co-crew chief for [[John Force]], the other crew chief is [[Austin Coil]]. In the first round at Arizona, [[Antron Brown]] lost a wheel and crashed into the wall. Although Brown was uninjured in the accident, the wheel struck a female spectator who was killed. Because of weather conditions, the Pro Stock event at the same meet was cancelled after one round. The eight first-round winners competed as part of second-round qualifying at the next round.{{cite news|url=http://www.insideline.com/car-news/nhra-spectator-killed-by-crash-debris-at-arizona.html|title=Spectator Killed by Crash Debris at Arizona|date=2010-02-22|accessdate=2010-02-22|work=Inside Line|publisher=Edmunds Inc.| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100224062157/http://www.insideline.com/car-news/nhra-spectator-killed-by-crash-debris-at-arizona.html| archivedate= 24 February 2010 | deadurl= no}} Just two days after [[John Force]] won a record 15th Funny Car world championship, his crew chief, NHRA Hall of Fame member Austin Coil, resigned from John Force Racing.{{cite news | url = http://www.nhra.com/story/2010/11/16/coil-resigns-from-john-force-racing-but-eyes-possible-2012-return-to-racing/ | title = Coil resigns from John Force Racing but eyes possible 2012 return to racing | date = 2010-11-16 | accessdate = 2010-11-16 | publisher = National Hot Rod Association | work = nhra.com | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20101229043144/http://www.nhra.com/story/2010/11/16/coil-resigns-from-john-force-racing-but-eyes-possible-2012-return-to-racing/# | archivedate = 2010-12-29 | deadurl = yes | df = }} In his announcement, Coil stated he wanted to take at least a year off, but left the door open to a return to racing in 2012. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.nhra.com Official website] * [https://secure.nhra.powerade.com/contest/podcast.asp Official NHRA Drag Racing Podcasts]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.dragracecentral.com/ Drag Race Central] The Latest NHRA News and Analysis {{NHRA Drag Racing years}} [[Category:NHRA Mello Yello Drag Racing Series]] [[Category:2010 in American motorsport|NHRA Full Throttle]]

{{unreferenced|date=February 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Year nav|-499}} {{BC year in topic|499}} [[File:Ionian Revolt Campaign Map.png|{{Largethumb}}|right|Main events of the [[Ionian Revolt]]]] __NOTOC__ Year '''499 BC''' was a year of the [[Roman calendar|pre-Julian Roman calendar]]. In the [[Roman Empire]] it was known as the '''Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus''' (or, less frequently, '''year 255 ''[[Ab urbe condita]]''''').{{fact|date=May 2014}} The denomination 499 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the [[Anno Domini]] [[calendar era]] became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.
== Events == <onlyinclude>
=== By place ===
==== Greece ==== * After a failed attack on the rebellious island of [[Naxos Island|Naxos]] in [[502 BC]] (on behalf of the [[Achaemenid Empire|Persians]]), [[Aristagoras]], to save himself from the [[Anger|wrath]] of Persia, plans a revolt with the [[Miletus|Milesians]] and the other Ionians. With the encouragement of [[Histiaeus]] (his father-in-law and former tyrant of [[Miletus]]), [[Aristagoras]], governor of [[Miletus]], induces the Ionian cities of [[Asia Minor]] to revolt against Persia, thus instigating the [[Ionian Revolt]] and beginning the [[Greco-Persian Wars]] between [[Ancient Greece|Greece]] and Persia. The pro-Persian tyrant of [[Mytilene]] is stoned to death. * [[Miltiades the Younger]], the ruler of the [[Thracian Chersonese]], which has been under Persian [[suzerainty]] since approximately [[514 BC]], joins the Ionian revolt. He seizes the islands of [[Lemnos]] and [[Imbros]] from the Persians. * Aristagoras seeks help with the revolt against the Persians from [[Cleomenes I]], king of [[Sparta]], but the Spartans are unwilling to respond. </onlyinclude> == Births == *

{{EngvarB|date=May 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}}
'''The Abbottabad Commission''' was a [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|judicial]] inquiry commissioned to provide reports on the circumstantial events leading up to the [[United States]] decision to take [[Operation Neptune Spear|unilateral]] military actions in [[Abbottabad]] in [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa|Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa Province]] of [[Pakistan]], with the objective of neutralizing [[al-Qaeda]] leader [[Osama bin Laden]] on May 2, 2011.<ref name="dawn20121208">{{cite web|url=http://dawn.com/2012/12/08/abbottabad-commission-completes-report-on-osama-killing/|title=Abbottabad Commission completes probe report on Osama killing|date=8 December 2012|work=Dawn|accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref> Constituted by the [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]] of Pakistan on the request of the [[Government of Pakistan|Government]] of Pakistan on 21 June 2011, the commission was chaired by the [[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan|Senior Justice]] [[Javaid Iqbal]] and other members selected by the supreme court.
The Commission critically evaluated and provided analysis on "ascertain full facts regarding the presence of Osama bin Laden in Pakistan" and thoroughly "investigated circumstances and facts regarding the American operation in Abbottabad on 2 May 2011." The commission extensively interviewed local residents of Abbottabad, government ministers, military officials, and investigative espionage journalists.
The Commission's [[Abbottabad Report|final report]] included 300 witnesses and reviewed 3,000 official documents over two years. The final report was based on public testimonies and was prepared by the Senior Justice Javid Iqbal. The reports were submitted to Prime Minister [[Raja Pervez Ashraf|Pervez Ashraf]] on January 2013 and were marked as "classified" by the government. No details were made public despite the requests of officials. By early 2012, only a few portions were released to the media. The [[Abbottabad Commission Report]] was released by [[Al Jazeera]] on 8 July 2013.<ref name="AlJaz20130708">{{cite web|last=HAshim|first=Asad|title=Leaked report shows bin Laden's 'hidden life'|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2013/07/20137813412615531.html|publisher=Al Jazeera English|accessdate=8 July 2013|date=8 July 2013}}</ref>
==Overview of Abbottabad Commission== {{main|Death of Osama bin Laden}}
===Members and priorities of the Commissions===
The commission was headed by Justice [[Javaid Iqbal]] and included [[Pakistan Senate|Senator]] [[Ashraf Qazi|Ashraf Kazi]], [[Lieutenant-General]] (retired) [[Nadeem Ahmad]], civil servant [[Nargis Sethi]] and former [[Inspector-General]] of [[Frontier Police]], Abbas Khan.<ref name="dawn20121208" />
After much criticism, Prime Minister [[Yousaf Raza Gillani]] formed the commission under Senior Justice Javed Iqbal and its members included:<ref name="Express Tribune, 2011 (Ghauri)">{{cite news|last=Irfan Ghauri|title=Abbottabad fiasco: Government names probe commission|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/179573/gilani-forms-independent-commission-for-abbottabad-raid/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Express Tribune|date=1 June 2011}}</ref> *[[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of Pakistan|Senior Justice]] Javed Iqbal<ref name="Express Tribune, 2011 (Ghauri)"/>— Chairman **Senior Justice [[Fakhruddin G. Ebrahim|Fakhruddin Ebrahim]]<ref name="Express Tribune, 06/2011"/>‡ **[[Lieutenant-General]] [[Nadeem Ahmad]]<ref name="Express Tribune, 2011 (Ghauri)"/>— [[Military Intelligence of Pakistan|Military Intelligence]] investigative member **[[Inspector-General]] [[Abbas Khan]]<ref name="Express Tribune, 2011 (Ghauri)"/>— Internal security member **Senator [[Ashraf Qazi|Ashraf Jahangir Qazi]]<ref name="Express Tribune, 2011 (Ghauri)"/>— Political science and foreign affairs member **Senior Justice [[Rana Bhagwandas]]<ref name="Express Tribune, 06/2011">{{cite news|last=Ghauri|first=Irfan|title=Abbottabad commission crashes before taking off|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/180669/abbottabad-commission-crashes-before-taking-off/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Express Tribune, 06/2011|date=1 June 2011}}</ref>†— Legal and philosophical affairs member ***‡''Senior Justice [[Fakhruddin G. Ebrahim|Fakhruddin Ebrahim]] resigned due to poor health'' ***†''Senior Justice [[Rana Bhagwandas]] joined the commission after Ebrahim resigning''
The terms of reference of the commission were ** to ascertain full facts regarding the presence of Osama bin Laden in Pakistan; **investigate circumstances and facts regarding the US operation in Abbottabad on 2 May 2011; ** determine the nature, background, and causes of lapses of authorities concerned, if any; **make consequential recommendations.<ref name="dawn20110622">{{cite web|url=http://dawn.com/2011/06/22/abbottabad-raid-and-saleem-shahzad-commissions-set-up/|title=Abbottabad raid and Saleem Shahzad commissions set up|last=Ghumman|first=Khwar|date=22 June 2011|work=Dawn|accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref>
===Political response===
The conservative party, [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)|Pakistan Muslim League]] (PML), criticized the Prime Minister [[Yousaf Raza Gillani|Gillani]] for a failure to initiate a probe into the May [[Operation Neptune Spear|US incursion]] in accordance with the resolution adopted during the joint secret session of parliament.<ref name="Express Tribune, 05/29/2011">{{cite news|last=Correspondent|title=PML-N pushes for Abbottabad raid probe|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/178214/pml-n-pushes-for-abbottabad-raid-probe/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Express Tribune, 29 May 2011|date=29 May 2011}}</ref> Despite Prime Minister Gillani addressing his concerns to PML,<ref name="Tex, 05/2012">{{cite news|last=Mannan|first=Abdul|title=Abbottabad probe: Independent commission only to fulfil formalities?|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/173151/abbottabad-probe-independent-commission-only-to-fulfil-formalities/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Tex, 05/2012|date=21 May 2011}}</ref> the party pushed for an independent commission to be formed.<ref name="Express Tribune, 05/29/2011"/> The PML persuasion was that "it did not want the [[Pakistan Armed Forces|armed forces]] to face another fiasco like the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|1971 war]] or the [[Kargil war|Kargil misadventure]].<ref name="Tex, May 24th, 2011.">{{cite news|last=Zaman|first=Kamar|title=Security breach: PML-N reiterates demand for independent commission|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/174707/security-breach-pml-n-reiterates-demand-for-independent-commission/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Tex, 24 May 2011.|date=24 May 2011}}</ref>
After meeting with the Lieutenant-General [[Ahmed Shuja Pasha|Shuja' Pasha]] of the [[ISI (Pakistan)|ISI]], [[Law Minister of Pakistan|Justice minister]] [[Moula Bakhsh Chandio|Bux Chandio]] hinted that the commission would be formed after the consultation.<ref name="Tex,May 17, 2011">{{cite news|last=correspondents|title=Abbottabad incursion: 'Commission to be constituted soon'|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/170196/abbottabad-incursion-commission-to-be-constituted-soon/|accessdate=27 June 2013|newspaper=Tex,17 May 2011|date=17 May 2011}}</ref> In June 2011, Prime Minister Gillani announced to form the commission under [[Supreme Court of Pakistan|Supreme Court]]'s Senior Justice Javed Iqbal.<ref name="Express Tribune, 2011 (Ghauri)"/>
===Interview and studies=== {{Main|Abbottabad Report}} The Commission extensively interviewed 300 people and among the notable people summoned and testified to the commission were: **[[Hina Rabbani Khar|Hina Khar]]— [[Foreign Minister of Pakistan|Foreign minister]] at that time **[[Ahmad Mukhtar]]— [[Minister of Defence (Pakistan)|Defense minister]] during this period. **[[Ziauddin Butt]]— former director-general of the [[ISI (Pakistan)|ISI]] (in 1999). **[[Lieutenant-General]] [[Nadeem Taj]]— director-general of [[Military Intelligence of Pakistan|Military Intelligence]] (MI) **[[Ijaz Shah]].<ref name="Dawn20120320">{{cite web|url=http://dawn.com/2012/03/20/abbottabad-commission-summons-former-spy-chiefs/|title=Abbottabad Commission summons former spy chiefs|date=20 March 2012|work=Dawn|accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref>— former director-general of [[Intelligence Bureau (Pakistan)|Intelligence Bureau]] (IB), working under former President [[Pervez Musharraf]] from 2004–07
The 700-page report was prepared after the commission interviewed 300 witnesses and reviewed 3000 documents.<ref name="ET20130104">{{cite web|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/488865/abbottabad-commission-report-on-bin-laden-out-but-not-public/|title=Abbottabad Commission: Report on bin Laden out, but not public|date=4 January 2013|work=The Express Tribune|accessdate=1 March 2013}}</ref> The commission submitted its report to prime minister [[Raja Pervaiz Ashraf]] in January 2013.<ref name="dawn20130104">{{cite web|url=http://dawn.com/2013/01/04/abbottabad-commission-submits-report-to-pm/|title=Abbottabad commission submits report to PM|date=4 January 2013|work=Dawn|accessdate=28 February 2013}}</ref>

__NOTOC__ {{Infobox award | name = Albert Leon Whiteman Memorial Prize | image = | imagesize = | description = Notable exposition on the [[history of mathematics]]. | presenter = [[American Mathematical Society]] (AMS) | country = [[United States]] | reward = US $5,000 | year = 1998 | year2 = 2015 | website = {{URL|http://www.ams.org/prizes/whiteman-prize.html}} }} The '''Albert Leon Whiteman Memorial Prize''' is awarded by the [[American Mathematical Society]] for notable exposition and exceptional scholarship in the [[history of mathematics]].
The prize was established in 1998 with funds provided by Sally Whiteman in memory of her late husband Albert Leon Whiteman. Originally it was awarded every 4 years with the first prized handed out in 2001. Since 2009 the prize is awarded every 3 years and carries a prize money of $5000.
==Past recipients== *2001 [[Thomas W. Hawkins, Jr.|Thomas Hawkins]] *2005 [[Harold M. Edwards]] *2009 [[Jeremy Gray]] *2012 [[Joseph Dauben]] *2015 [[Umberto Bottazzini]] *2018 [[Karen Parshall]]

'''Alcohol advertising''' is the [[advertising|promotion]] of [[alcoholic beverage]]s by [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] producers through a variety of [[mass media|media]]. Along with [[tobacco advertising]], alcohol advertising is one of the most highly regulated forms of [[marketing]]. Some or all forms of alcohol advertising is banned in some countries. There have been some important studies about alcohol advertising published, such as J.P. Nelson's in 2000.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/cf_dev/AbsByAuth.cfm?per_id=51224 | title=Author Page for Jon P. Nelson | work=[[SSRN]] | accessdate=January 21, 2017}}</ref>
Scientific research, health agencies and universities have, over the decades, been able to demonstrate a correlation between alcohol beverage advertising and alcohol consumption, especially among initially non-drinking youth.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Grenard|first=Jerry L.|last2=Dent|first2=Clyde W.|last3=Stacy|first3=Alan W.|date=2013|title=Exposure to Alcohol Advertisements and Teenage Alcohol-Related Problems|journal=Pediatrics|volume=131|issue=2|pages=369–379|doi=10.1542/peds.2012-1480|pmc=3557408|pmid=23359585}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Snyder|first=Leslie B.|last2=Milici|first2=Frances Fleming|last3=Slater|first3=Michael|last4=Sun|first4=Helen|last5=Strizhakova|first5=Yuliya|date=2006|title=Effects of Alcohol Advertising Exposure on Drinking Among Youth|url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/fullarticle/204410?resultClick=1|journal=Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine|language=en|volume=160|issue=1|pages=|doi=10.1001/archpedi.160.1.18|issn=1072-4710|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=P.|last2=Bruijn|first2=A. de|last3=Angus|first3=K.|last4=Gordon|first4=R.|last5=Hastings|first5=G.|date=2009|title=Impact of Alcohol Advertising and Media Exposure on Adolescent Alcohol Use: A Systematic Review of Longitudinal Studies|url=https://academic.oup.com/alcalc/article/44/3/229/178279|journal=Alcohol and Alcoholism|language=en|volume=44|issue=3|pages=229–243|doi=10.1093/alcalc/agn115|issn=0735-0414|via=}}</ref> However, there is an equally significant body of research positing that alcohol advertising does not ''cause'' higher consumption and rather merely reflects greater public demand, with many commentators suggesting that effective alcohol campaigns only increase a producer's market share and also brand loyalty.<ref>J.P. Nelson, "What is Learned from Longitudinal Studies of Advertising and Youth Drinking and Smoking?" International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health, 7(3), March 2010, pp. 870–926.</ref><ref>Frankena, M., Cohen, M., Daniel, T., Ehrlich, L., Greenspun, N., and Kelman, D. Alcohol Advertising, Consumption and Abuse. In: Federal Trade Commission. ''Recommendations of the Staff of the Federal Trade Commission: Omnibus Petition for Regulation of Unfair and Deceptive Alcoholic Beverage Marketing Practices'', Docket No. 209-46. Washington, DC: Federal Trade Commission, 1985.</ref><ref>Sanders, James. Alcohol Advertisements Do Not Encourage Alcohol Abuse Among Teens. In: Wekesser, Carol (ed.) ''Alcoholism''. San Diego, CA: Greenhaven Press, 1994. Pp. 132–135, p. 133.</ref>
==Target marketing== The [[target market|intended audience]] of the alcohol [[advertising campaign]]s have changed over the years, with some brands being specifically targeted towards a particular [[demographic profile|demographic]]. Some drinks are traditionally seen as a male drink, particularly [[beer]]s<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thedrinksbusiness.com/2015/10/beer-still-perceived-as-a-mans-drink/|title=Beer Still 'Perceived as a Man's Drink'|last=Eads|first=Lauren|date=2015|website=The Drinks Business|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=26 March 2018}}</ref> and [[whiskies]], while others are drunk by females. Some brands have allegedly been specifically developed to appeal to people that would not normally drink that kind of beverage. These ads may contribute to underage consumption and binge drinking.<ref name=":0" /> In 2011 a study found that twenty-two percent of twelfth graders had binge drank in the past two weeks,<ref>Johnston, L. D., O’Malley, P. M., Bachman, J. G., & Schulenberg, J. E. (2012). ''[http://monitoringthefuture.org/pubs/monographs/mtf-overview2011.pdf Monitoring the Future national results on adolescent drug use: Overview of key findings, 2011]''. Ann Arbor: Institute for Social Research, The University of Michigan.</ref> this figure doubled for kids in college.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=White|first=Aaron|last2=Hingson|first2=Ralph|date=2014|title=The Burden of Alcohol Use|journal=Alcohol Research : Current Reviews|volume=35|issue=2|pages=201–218|issn=2168-3492|pmc=908712|pmid=24881329}}</ref> Studies suggest that the use of alcohol before the brain fully develops can alter or negatively affect the development of the brain.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ewing|first=Sarah W.Feldstein|last2=Sakhardande|first2=Ashok|last3=Blakemore|first3=Sarah-Jayne|date=2014|title=The effect of alcohol consumption on the adolescent brain: A systematic review of MRI and fMRI studies of alcohol-using youth|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2213158214000874|journal=NeuroImage: Clinical|volume=5|pages=420–437|via=ScienceDirect}}</ref>
One area in which the alcohol industry has faced criticism and tightened legislation is in their alleged targeting of young people. Central to this is the development of [[alcopop]]s – [[sweetness|sweet-tasting]], brightly coloured drinks with names that may appeal to a younger audience. However, numerous government and other reports have failed to support that allegation.<ref name="Minors. Los Angeles Times 2006, pp. 357-69">(FTC Says Alcohol Type Not Aimed at Minors. Los Angeles Times, June 5, 2002;</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://archive.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2010/11/20/targeting_youth_to_start_drinking/|title=Targeting youth to start drinking|last=Jackson|first=Derrick Z.|date=2010-11-20|work=Boston Globe|access-date=2018-03-27|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2017/oct/04/australia-ignoring-power-to-stop-alcohol-ads-reaching-children-experts-say|title=Australia failing to stop alcohol ads reaching children, experts say|last=Davey|first=Melissa|date=2017-10-04|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref>
There have been several disputes over whether alcohol advertisements are targeting teens. There happens to be heavy amounts of alcohol advertising that appears to make drinking fun and exciting. Alcohol advertisements can be commonly seen in virtually any medium, they are especially known for sponsoring sporting events, concerts, magazines, and they are widely found on the internet.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.quitnow.gov.au/internet/anpha/publishing.nsf/Content/F641F67C6D6F52C5CA257C86001D5F19/$File/Alcohol%20Advertising%20DRAFT%20REPORT%20MASTER%20DOCUMENT%2020.2.14%20(D14-3314).pdf|title=Alcohol Advertising: The effectiveness of current regulatory codes in addressing community concern|last=|first=|date=2014|website=Australian National Preventative Health Agency|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=26 March 2018}}</ref> Most of the vendors’ websites require an age of 21 to enter, but there is no restriction besides simply entering a birth date. A study done by the [[American Journal of Public Health]] concluded that Boston train passengers between the ages of 11 and 18 saw an alcohol-related advertisement everyday.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gentry|first=Elisabeth|last2=Poirier|first2=Katie|last3=Wilkinson|first3=Tiana|last4=Nhean|first4=Siphannay|last5=Nyborn|first5=Justin|last6=Siegel|first6=Michael|date=2011-10-01|title=Alcohol Advertising at Boston Subway Stations: An Assessment of Exposure by Race and Socioeconomic Status|url=http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/abs/10.2105/AJPH.2011.300159|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=101|issue=10|pages=1936–1941|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2011.300159|issn=0090-0036|pmc=3222337}}</ref> There have been studies similar to this, which supports the allegation that underage consumption of alcohol is in correlation with the exposure of alcohol ads.<ref name=":1" /> In response, many cities have recognized the effect of alcohol-related ads on adolescents and in some cities these advertisements have been banned on public transportation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://adage.com/article/cmo-strategy/new-york-city-buses-trains-ban-alcohol-ads/311057/|title=As Alcohol Ads Sprawl Elsewhere, New York Buses and Trains Go Dry|last=Schultz|first=E.J.|date=2017|work=AdAge|access-date=2018-03-27|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref> It is difficult to make definite allegations regarding youth exposure to these types of advertisements but it is necessary to find ways in which these allegations may be limited.<ref>[http://web.ebscohost.com/ehost/detail?sid=115e9800-0c0b-4970-b6bd-ea87983bc2e4%40sessionmgr13&vid=6&hid=19&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZSZzY29wZT1zaXRl#db=a9h&AN=47513354 Web.ebscohost.com]. {{paywall}}</ref>
The National Household Survey on Drug Abuse reports the rates of binge alcohol use in 2008 were 1.5 percent among 12 or 13 years old, 6.9 percent among 14 or 15 years old, 17.2 percent among 16 or 17 years old, 33.7 percent among persons aged 18 to 20.<ref>{{cite report| author = Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration| date = 2009| title = Results from the 2008 National Survey on Drug Use and Health: National Findings| url = http://www.dpft.org/resources/NSDUHresults2008.pdf| publisher = Office of Applied Studies, NSDUH Series H-36, HHS Publication No. SMA 09-4434| publication-place = Rockville, MD| access-date = November 8, 2017}}</ref> In 2009, the rates for each group of underage alcohol usage increased by a fourth.<ref>{{cite report| author = Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration| date = 2010| title = Results from the 2009 National Survey on Drug Use and Health: Volume I. Summary of National Findings| url = http://www.gmhc.org/files/editor/file/a_pa_nat_drug_use_survey.pdf| publisher = Office of Applied Studies, NSDUH Series H-38A, HHS Publication No. SMA 10-4586Findings| publication-place = Rockville, MD| access-date = November 8, 2017}}</ref>
According to 2001 College Alcohol Study (CAS), continuous alcohol promotions and advertisements including lowering prices on certain types of alcohol on a college campus have increased the percentage of alcohol consumption of that college community. Alcohol advertising on college campuses have also shown to increase binge drinking among students. However, it is concluded that the consistency of these special promotions and ads could also be useful in reducing binge drinking and other related drinking problems on campus. (Kuo, 2000, [[Henry Wechsler|Wechsler]] 2000, Greenberg 2000, Lee 2000).<ref> {{cite journal |author =Meichun Kuo |author2=[[Henry Wechsler]] |author3=Patty Greenberg |author4=Hang Lee |title=The marketing of alcohol to college students |work=[[American Journal of Preventive Medicine]] |volume=25 |issue=3 |pages=204–211 |date=October 2003 |doi=10.1016/S0749-3797(03)00200-9 }}</ref> * Results from one study indicate that beer advertisements are a significant predictor of an adolescent's knowledge, preference, and loyalty for beer brands, as well as current drinking behavior and intentions to drink (Gentile, 2001). * Television advertising changes attitudes about drinking. Young people report more positive feelings about drinking and their own likelihood to drink after viewing alcohol ads (Austin, 1994; Grube, 1994). * The alcohol industry spends $2 billion per year on all media advertising (Strasburger, 1999). * The beer brewing industry itself spent more than $770 million on television ads and $15 million on radio ads in 2000 (Center for Science in the Public Interest, 2002).
Research clearly indicates that, in addition to parents and peers, alcohol advertising and marketing significantly affect youth decisions to drink. (The Center on Alcohol Marketing and Youth [CAMY]).
"While many factors may influence an underage person's drinking decisions, including among other things parents, peers and the media, there is reason to believe that advertising also plays a role." (Federal Trade Commission, Self-Regulation in the Alcohol Industry, 1999)
Parents and peers substantially affect youth decisions to drink. However, research clearly indicates that alcohol advertising and marketing also have a significant effect by influencing youth and adult expectations and attitudes, and helping to create an environment that promotes underage drinking.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.camy.org/resources/fact-sheets/alcohol-advertising-and-youth/index.html|title=Alcohol Advertising and Youth|last=Stephenson|first=Steve|website=Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-26}}</ref>
Even though people these days must put themselves into that situation, David H. Jernigan (2005: 314) underlines how “more than fifteen percent of twelve-year-olds will be likely to create the situation where youth are more likely per capita to see the magazine than adults over twenty-one years, the legal drinking age in the United States”.
===Malt liquor=== {{Main|Malt liquor#Advertising}}
The target market for [[malt liquor]] in the United States has been among the [[African-American]] and [[Hispanic]] populations in cities. Advertisers use themes of power and sexual dominance to appeal to customers. Critics have objected to ads targeting this segment of the population, which suffers disproportionately high rates of alcohol-related illness and poor access to medical care.
=== Among adolescents === Peter Anderson and his colleagues performed longitudinal studies and concluded that “alcohol advertising and promotion increases the likelihood that adolescents will start to use alcohol, and to drink more if they are already using alcohol.”<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Peter|last2=Bruijn|first2=Avalon de|last3=Angus|first3=Kathryn|last4=Gordon|first4=Ross|last5=Hastings|first5=Gerard|date=2009-05-01|title=Impact of Alcohol Advertising and Media Exposure on Adolescent Alcohol Use: A Systematic Review of Longitudinal Studies|url=http://alcalc.oxfordjournals.org/content/44/3/229|journal=Alcohol and Alcoholism|language=en|volume=44|issue=3|pages=229–243|doi=10.1093/alcalc/agn115|issn=0735-0414|pmid=19144976}}</ref> Elizabeth D. Waiters, Andrew J. Treno, and Joel W. Grube’s discussions with a sample of youth, ages 9–15, support this claim. They found that these youth saw the purpose of beer commercials is to urge people to buy the product based on not only its quality, but also on “its relationship to sexual attractiveness.” They see the “attractive young adults drink beer to personally rewarding ends” and the “youth-oriented music” and are influenced to drink alcohol.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Waiters|first=Elizabeth D.|last2=Treno|first2=Andrew J.|last3=Grube|first3=Joel W.|date=2001-12-01|title=Alcohol Advertising and Youth: A Focus-Group Analysis of What Young People Find Appealing in Alcohol Advertising|url=http://cdx.sagepub.com/content/28/4/695|journal=Contemporary Drug Problems|language=en|volume=28|issue=4|pages=695–718|doi=10.1177/009145090102800409|issn=0091-4509}}</ref>
==Advertising around the world== The [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) has specified that the advertising and promotion of alcohol needs to be controlled. In September 2005, the WHO Euro Region adopted a Framework for Alcohol Policy for the Region. This has 5 ethical principles which includes "All children and adolescents have the right to grow up in an environment protected from the negative consequences of alcohol consumption and, to the extent possible, from the promotion of alcoholic beverages".<ref> {{cite web |title=Framework for alcohol policy in the WHO European Region |url=http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/79396/E88335.pdf |date=April 4, 2006 |publisher=[[World Health Organization]] Regional Office for Europe |format=PDF |accessdate=June 6, 2013 }}</ref>
Cross-border television advertising within the [[European Union]] was previously regulated by the 1989 Television without Frontiers Directive, a [[Harmonisation of law|harmonisation]] measure designed to remove barriers to international trade as part of the [[common market]].<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:1989:298:0023:0030:EN:PDF Council Directive 89/552/EEC of 3 October 1989 on the coordination of certain provisions laid down by Law, Regulation or Administrative Action in Member States concerning the pursuit of television broadcasting activities]</ref> Article 15 of this Directive sets out the restrictions on alcohol advertising: * "it may not be aimed specifically at minors or, in particular, depict minors consuming these beverages; * it shall not link the consumption of alcohol to enhanced physical performance or to driving; * it shall not create the impression that the consumption of alcohol contributes towards social or sexual success; * it shall not claim that alcohol has therapeutic qualities or that it is a stimulant, a sedative or a means of resolving personal conflicts; * it shall not encourage immoderate consumption of alcohol or present abstinence or moderation in a negative light; * it shall not place emphasis on high alcoholic content as being a positive quality of the beverages."
This article on alcohol advertising restrictions is implemented in each EU country largely through the self-regulatory bodies dealing with advertising.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://adage.com/article/global-news/alcohol-advertisers-launch-regulation-pact-europe/234141/|title=Alcohol Advertisers Launch Self-Regulation Pact in Europe|last=Wentz|first=Laurel|date=2012|work=AdAge|access-date=2018-03-27|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
The EU law 'TV without Frontiers' Directive has subsequently been expanded to cover new media formats such as digital television. Now called the 'Audiovisual Media Services Directive', the provisions regarding restrictions on alcohol advertising are laid out in Article 22 and are identical to the above.<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2010:095:0001:0024:EN:PDF Directive 2010/13/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 10 March 2010 on the coordination of certain provisions laid down by law, regulation or administrative action in Member States concerning the provision of audiovisual media services (Audiovisual Media Services Directive)]</ref>
Some countries, such as [[France]], [[Norway]], [[Russia]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Russia slaps ban on alcohol advertising in media|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-18960770|publisher=BBC News}}</ref> [[Ukraine]],<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/56294/ Tobacco, alcohol advertising bans take effect in printed media], [[Kyiv Post]] (January 1, 2010)</ref> [[Myanmar]], [[Sri Lanka]],<ref name="SriLanka" /> and [[Kenya]] have banned all alcohol advertising on television and billboard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/4080074.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Africa - Kenya to outlaw alcohol adverts|publisher=|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref>
===United States=== {{see also|Alcohol advertising on college campuses|Alcohol consumption by youth in the United States}}
In the United States, spirits advertising has [[self-regulatory bodies]] that create standards for the ethical advertising of alcohol. The special concern is where advertising is placed.
Currently, the standard is that alcohol advertisements can only be placed in media where 70% of the audience is over the legal drinking age. Alcohol advertising's creative messages should not be designed to appeal to people under the age of 21, for example, using cartoon characters as spokespeople is discouraged. Advertising cannot promote brands based on alcohol content or its effects. Advertising must not encourage irresponsible drinking. Another issue in media placement is whether media vendors will accept alcohol advertising. The decision to accept an individual ad or a category of advertising is always at the discretion of the owner or publisher of a media outlet.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.alcohol.org/|title=Did You Know?: How Advertising of Alcohol in the U.S. is Regulated|last=|first=|date=|website=Alcohol.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref>
In 1991, U.S. Surgeon General [[Antonia Novello]] criticized alcoholic beverage companies for "unabashedly targeting teenagers" with "sexual imagery, cartoons, and rock and rap music" in television and print ads.{{refn|name=Davidson}}{{rp|113–5}} The [[Federal Trade Commission]] conducted an investigation in 2002 into possible targeting to those under the age of 21. However, this investigation and those of some scholars have not found evidence of such targeting.<ref name="Minors. Los Angeles Times 2006, pp. 357-69"/><ref>Nelson, Jon P. Alcohol advertising in magazines: Do beer, wine, and spirits ads target youth? ''[[Contemporary Economic Policy]]'', July 2006, pp. 357-69).</ref> Concerns exist that irresponsible advertising practices or "pushing the envelope" with audience composition may lead to permanent legislation governing the advertising of beverage alcohol.<ref>[http://www.discus.org/industry/code/code.htm "Code"]. Discus.org. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050405235706/http://www.discus.org/industry/code/code.htm |date=April 5, 2005 }}</ref>
===Asia===
In [[Malaysia]], alcohol advertising on radio and televisions was outlawed in 1995. On Malaysian television, alcohol advertising is not shown before 10:00 pm and during Malay-language programs. However, non-Malay newspapers and magazines are allowed to continue alcohol advertising. [[Supermarket]]s and [[hypermarket]]s have also been criticized for advertising alcohol products on trolleys, which is controversial because Islam is the state religion of the country. After the ban of alcohol advertising on Malaysian radio and televisions, they continued to build the brands with sponsorships of concerts and entertainment events.
In [[Singapore]], alcohol advertisement is not allowed to be shown during programmes intended for children and young persons and during Malay-language programmes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iogt.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Alcohol-Advertising_A-Global-Legal-Perspective.pdf|title=Alcohol Advertising: A Global Legal Perspective|last=|first=|date=2011|website=Global Advertising Lawyers Alliance|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref>
In [[Indonesia]], alcohol advertising was legal in the 1990s, but have since been completely banned.<ref>[http://www.who.int/substance_abuse/publications/policy_indonesia.pdf 2004 Global Status Report: Alcohol Policy]. World Health Organisation. Retrieved 2018-03-27.</ref>
In [[Hong Kong]], alcohol advertising is not allowed to be shown during Family Viewing Hour programmes.
In the [[Philippines]], alcohol advertising is allowed. Alcohol warning is also shown in the end of the advertisement explaining with the words: "Drink Moderately". In 2012, the warning was changed to "Drink Responsibly".
In Thailand, alcohol advertisements are still allowed, but must accompanied by a warning message. See [[Alcohol advertising in Thailand]].
In [[Sri Lanka]], public advertising on alcohol is banned totally since 2006.<ref name="SriLanka"> {{cite news|title=Sri Lanka bans public smoking, alcohol, tobacco advertising |url=http://www.asiantribune.com/node/944 |newspaper=[[Asian Tribune]] |date=July 6, 2006 |accessdate=June 6, 2013 }}</ref>
In South Korea, public advertising on alcohol is only allowed after 10:00 pm.
===Europe=== In Russia, advertising alcohol products is banned from almost all media (including television and billboards) since January 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-18960770|title=Russia bans alcohol ads in media|date=2012-07-23|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-27|language=en-GB}}</ref> Before that, alcohol advertising was restricted from using images of people drinking since mid-2000's.
In Sweden, since 2010 advertisements are legal for wine and beer, but not on television and radio. Non-periodic magazines are allowed to advertise alcoholic beverages above 15%.<ref>[http://www.notisum.se/rnp/sls/lag/20101622.htm Alkohollag (2010:1622)]</ref> These advertisements must contain warnings, but which are worded less strongly than the warnings on tobacco products - for example, "[[Fetal alcohol syndrome|Avoid drinking while pregnant]]," as opposed to "[[Tobacco packaging warning messages#Sweden|smoking kills]]." These rules were introduced into the law 2010<ref>[http://rkrattsbaser.gov.se/sfsr?fritext=1994%3A1738&sort=desc&post_id=1 Regeringskansliets rättsdatabaser Alkohollag (1994:1738)]</ref> based on the provisions of an [[EU directive]], {{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} provisionally applied by Swedish newspapers since 2005. Before that alcohol advertisements were forbidden, except for "class 1 beer" or "[[light beer]]." Such advertisements were common, as stronger beers which shared a name with advertised light beers, may have benefit from this.
In Finland, [[Parliament of Finland]] decided to ban alcohol outdoor advertising, except during sport events. This new law is going to take place in January 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://lib.eduskunta.fi/Resource.phx/kirjasto/oikeudellinentieto/tietopaketit/alkoholimainonta.htx | title=Alkoholimainonnan rajoittaminen | publisher=Eduskunnan Kirjasto | accessdate=14 November 2014|language=fi}}</ref>
In the United Kingdom, the [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority]] have banned several ads that don't comply with the restrictions in the EU directive.<ref>{{cite news|title=Strongbow's YouTube spoof and seven other banned alcohol adverts|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/34474456/strongbows-youtube-spoof-and-seven-other-banned-alcohol-adverts|work=BBC Newsbeat|date=8 October 2015}}</ref>
In Norway, Advertising on alcohol is banned totally since 1975.
In September 2017, Facebook announced it would allow users to hide all alcohol advertisements. The move is debated within the UK, as Alcohol Research UK group welcomed the change, while the Alcohol Standards Authority, said the UK already had some of the strictest rules in the world.<ref>{{cite news|title=Strongbow's YouTube spoof and seven other banned alcohol adverts|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-41332082|work=BBC News|date=20 September 2017}}</ref>
In November 2018, Ireland introduced a law banning alcohol advertisements near schools, children play areas, public transportation, and cinemas, as well as restricting visibility of alcohol products in stores. The legislation will take effect November 2019. <ref>{{cite news|title=Ireland’s minister for health Simon Harris has signed a “groundbreaking” law to ban alcohol advertising near schools and play areas and restrict visibility of alcohol in stores over the next two years.|url=https://www.thespiritsbusiness.com/2018/11/ireland-passes-ground-breaking-alcohol-advertising-law/|work=Spirits Business|date=6 November 2018}}</ref>
== Responsible drinking campaigns ==
There have been various campaigns to help prevent [[alcoholism]], under-age drinking and [[driving under the influence|drunk driving]]. The [[Portman Group]], an association of leading drinks producers in the UK, are responsible for various such campaigns. These include [[drinking culture|responsible drinking]], drink driving (and [[designated driver]]s), [[proof of age]] cards. The ''Drink Aware'' campaign,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://drinkaware.co.uk/|title=Home|publisher=|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref> for example, aims to educate people about how to drink sensibly and avoid [[binge drinking]]. The web site address is displayed as part of all of the adverts for products made by members of the group.
[[The Century Council]], financially supported by a group of alcoholic beverage distillers in the United States, promotes responsible decision-making regarding drinking or non-drinking and works to reduce all forms of irresponsible consumption. Since its founding in 1991, it has invested over 175 million dollars in its programs.
Many campaigns by the alcoholic beverage industry that advocate responsible drinking presuppose that drinking for recreational purposes is a positive activity and reinforce this idea as an example of sensible consumption. Persons who believe alcohol can never simultaneously be used "sensibly" and recreationally would obviously disagree with the focus or direction of these campaigns.
A controversial anti-drunk driving advertisement in South Africa has threatened the public with rape in prison. The campaign is still underway with no reported complaints to the advertising standards authorities.<ref> {{cite news |title=Drink-drive campaign gets ugly |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/drink-drive-campaign-gets-ugly-1.950728 |date=December 4, 2010 |newspaper=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|Independent Online]] |accessdate=June 6, 2013 }} </ref>
== Sponsorship in sport == [[File:Brad Keselowski, 2013 STP Gas Booster 500.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Miller Lite]] sponsored car of [[Brad Keselowski]] in the [[NASCAR]] [[Sprint Cup Series]]]] The [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]]ship of sporting events and sportspeople is banned in many countries. For example, the primary club competition in European [[rugby union]], the [[Heineken Cup]], is called the ''H Cup'' in [[France]] because of that country's restrictions on alcohol advertising. However, such sponsorship is still common in other areas, such as the [[United States]], although such sponsorship is controversial as children are often a target audience for major professional sports leagues.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rand.org/pubs/research_briefs/RB9073/index1.html | title=Forging the Link Between Alcohol Advertising and Underage Drinking | publisher=Rand Corporation | date=2006 | accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref><ref>[http://www.media-awareness.ca/english/resources/educational/teaching_backgrounders/alcohol/alcohol_ads_and_sports.cfm "Alcohol ads and sports"]. Media-awareness.ca. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110806133216/http://www.media-awareness.ca/english/resources/educational/teaching_backgrounders/alcohol/alcohol_ads_and_sports.cfm |date=August 6, 2011 }}</ref>
Alcohol advertising is common in [[motor racing]] competitions, and is particularly prominent in [[NASCAR]] and [[IndyCar]]. One major example of this was the [[Busch Series]] (now known as the Xfinity Series), sponsored by a brand of [[beer]] sold by [[Anheuser-Busch]]. That sponsorship, which started in the series' conversion from a national Late Model Sportsman races around the country to the present touring format in 1982, ended after 2007.
[[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]], the best-known Anheuser-Busch brand, has sponsored IndyCar drivers such as [[Mario Andretti]], [[Bobby Rahal]] and [[Paul Tracy]], as well as NASCAR Cup drivers such as [[Terry Labonte]], [[Neil Bonnett]], [[Darrell Waltrip]], [[Bill Elliott]], [[Dale Earnhardt Jr.]], [[Kasey Kahne]] and currently [[Kevin Harvick]]. Meanwhile, [[Miller Brewing Company|Miller]] has sponsored [[Al Unser]], [[Danny Sullivan]], Bobby Rahal, [[Rusty Wallace]], [[Kurt Busch]] and currently [[Brad Keselowski]].
Furthermore, NASCAR mandates drivers under 21 not be permitted to wear any alcohol-branded sticker on their cars. In cases with below drinking age drivers, a specialised "[[Pole position|Coors Pole Award - 21 Means 21]]" sticker is placed on such drivers' cars. One team, [[Petty Enterprises]], refuses to participate in alcohol advertising and forfeits all alcohol monies and bonuses.
For distilled spirits, teams must run a responsible drinking sticker clearly visible on the car. For [[Jack Daniel's]], the theme is "Pace Yourself, Drink Responsibly", and includes on NASCAR's Web site a waving yellow flag warning drinkers. For [[Crown Royal]], the television ads feature the car with the slogan "Be a champion, Drink Responsibly" and it acting as a pace car to drivers, warning them of responsibility. Jim Beam has radio ads and NASCAR mandated statements about alcohol control. None of the three, however, is a full-time sponsor, as they alternate sponsorship with other products unrelated to their firm on the car. (Jim Beam's parent, Fortune Brands, sometimes has its [[Moen (company)|Moen Faucet]]s replace Jim Beam on the car in selected races.)
Although [[tobacco]] companies have been the main source of financial backing in [[Formula One]], some alcohol brands have also been associated with the sport. For example, [[Martini & Rossi|Martini]] appears on the [[Williams F1]] car while [[Johnnie Walker]] has sponsored [[McLaren]] since 2006.
Anheuser-Busch, being a conglomerate with non-alcoholic properties, complies with the French alcohol advertising ban in Formula One by placing their Busch Entertainment theme park logos (mostly [[SeaWorld]]) where their Budweiser logo would appear on the [[Williams F1]] car at races where alcohol advertising is banned and in Middle Eastern countries, where alcohol advertising is discouraged. A few companies, however, have added responsible drinking campaigns with their sponsorship, notably the 1989–90 [[British Touring Car Championship|BTCC]] [[Ford Sierra|Ford Sierra RS500]] of [[Tim Harvey]] and [[Laurence Bristow]], which was sponsored by [[Labatt]]. Throughout the two seasons, the car bore a "Please Don't Drink and Drive" message.
Some stadiums, particularly in the U.S., bear the names of breweries or beer brands via [[naming rights]] arrangements, such as [[Busch Stadium]], [[Coors Field]], and [[Miller Park (Milwaukee)|Miller Park]]; those three venues are all in or near the cities of their headquarters.
[[Diageo]] are a major sponsor of many sporting events through their various brands. For example, [[Johnnie Walker]] sponsor the [[Johnnie Walker Championship at Gleneagles|Championship at Gleneagles]] and [[Johnnie Walker Classic|Classic]] [[golf]] tournaments along with the Team [[McLaren]] Formula One car.
[[Cricket]] is a sport with a large amount of alcohol sponsorship. [[The 2005 Ashes]], for example, featured sponsorship hoardings by brands such as [[Red Stripe]], [[Thwaites Brewery|Thwaites Lancaster Bomber]] and [[Wolf Blass|Wolf Blass wines]]. In nations like India and Sri Lanka where alcoholic advertising is generally prohibited, those regulations are rounded with distillers offering clothing lines and sports equipment marked with one of their brands or separate [[soft drink]] or [[bottled water]] lines within tournaments such as the [[Indian Premier League]] and test matches, such as [[United Spirits Limited]]'s [[McDowell's No.1]] and [[Pernod Ricard]]'s [[Royal Stag]].
[[Rugby union]] also has a substantial amount of alcohol sponsorship. The [[All Blacks]] feature [[Steinlager]] sponsorship prominently. The [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland national team]] has a long-established relationship with [[The Famous Grouse]], a brand of [[Scotch whisky]]. [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]] has a more recent relationship with the [[Brains Brewery|Brains]] brewery (But wear "Brawn" when playing in France), and the [[South Africa national rugby union team|Springboks]] of [[South Africa]] agreed for [[South African Breweries]] to put the Lion Lager, then, the [[SABMiller brands#Castle brewery|Castle Lager]] brand on their shirt until 2004. [[Magners]] was the title sponsor of the [[Pro14|Celtic League]], the top competition in [[Ireland]], [[Scotland]] and [[Wales]], [[Guinness]] is the title sponsor of the [[Guinness Premiership]], the top competition in [[England]], and the beer brand [[Tooheys New]] was the [[Australia]]n sponsor of the Southern Hemisphere [[Super Rugby|Super 14]] competition through the 2006 season. [[Bundaberg Rum]] is one of the sponsors of the [[Australia national rugby union team]].
[[Rugby league in Australia]] is sponsored by [[Victoria Bitter]] and [[Bundaberg Rum]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,21475237-23289,00.html|title=Nocookies|work=The Australian|accessdate=25 May 2016}}</ref>
== Campaigns ==
=== Guinness === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Guinness Toucan-ad.jpg|thumb|One of the [[Guinness]] advertising posters from the Gilroy Era of the 40's]] --> [[Guinness]]' iconic stature can be attributed in part to its advertising campaigns. One of the most notable and recognizable series of adverts was created by [[S.H. Benson]]'s advertising, primarily [[John Gilroy (artist)|John Gilroy]], in the 1930s and 1940s. Gilroy was responsible for creating posters which included such phrases such as "Guinness for Strength", "It's a Lovely Day for a Guinness", and most famously, "Guinness is Good For You". The posters featured Gilroy's distinctive artwork and more often than not featured animals such as a [[kangaroo]], [[ostrich]], [[Pinniped|seal]], [[lion]], and notably a [[toucan]], which has become as much a symbol of Guinness as the [[Trinity College Harp]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=I8KVxbDmAfkC&dq=gilroy+toucan+symbol&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=The Search for God and Guinness: A Biography of the Beer that Changed the World|last=Mansfield|first=Stephen|date=2009-10-12|publisher=Thomas Nelson|isbn=9781418580674|language=en}}</ref> Guinness advertising paraphernalia attracts high prices on the collectible market.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/money/goodness-guinness-memorabilias-worth-90000-8143706|title=How one man's passion for Guinness earned him £90,000|last=Read|first=Simon|date=2016-06-09|work=Mirror|access-date=2018-03-26|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>
In a campaign reminiscent of [[viral marketing]] techniques, one advert quickly appeared as a [[screensaver]] distributed over the [[Internet]]. It was a simple concept, featuring [[Dublin]] actor Joe McKinney dancing around the drink while it was given time to settle.<ref>{{Citation|last=haribokey|title=Guinness Anticipation Advert|date=2008-09-30|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S5HU5axz6GI|accessdate=2018-03-27}}</ref> The accompanying music ([[Mambo (music)|mambo]] tune ''Guaglione'' by [[Pérez Prado]]) was released as a single and reached number one on the Irish charts in September 1994 and number two on the [[1995 in British music|UK charts]] in May 1995 (see [[List of number-one singles of 1994 (Ireland)]] [[List of UK top 10 singles in 1995]]).
In Malaysia, Singapore, and Hong Kong, Guinness launched a $8 million advertising campaign using the fictional character of Adam King to promote the embodiment of Guinness as a man could be incredibly powerful. The advertising campaign was handled by advertising firm, [[Saatchi & Saatchi]].<ref>[http://www.josh.com.my/whoisadamking.com/ Who is Adam King?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070809072150/http://www.josh.com.my/whoisadamking.com/ |date=2007-08-09 }}</ref>
In [[Africa]], the character of [[Michael Power (advertisement)|Michael Power]] has been used since 1999 to boost sales.
Today, Guinness' principal television campaign in North America consists of [[limited animation]] commercials featuring two eccentric scientists in 19th-century dress complimenting one another's ideas as "brilliant!"<ref>{{Citation|last=boreczkizoli|title=guinness ad|date=2007-04-29|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DPKf7y1F-Q|accessdate=2018-03-27}}</ref>
=== Absolut === [[Absolut]] vodka is made in [[Sweden]] and was introduced to the United States in the year 1979. Its launch was a true challenge due to a variety of factors: Sweden was not perceived as a vodka-producing country, the bottle was very awkward for bartenders to use, and vodka was perceived as a cheap, tasteless drink. Absolut's advertising campaign by [[TBWA]] exploited the shape of the bottle to create clever advertisements that caused people to become involved in the advertising, and the brand took off.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.uxeria.com/en/absolut-the-story-of-the-unusual-bottle/|title=Absolut - the story of the (un)usual bottle - Uxeria Blog|last=Markiewicz|first=Magdalena|date=|website=blog.uxeria.com|language=en-GB|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref> Before Absolut, there were very few distinctions in the vodka category. Today there are regular, premium, and superpremium vodkas each at different price points and qualities. Flavoured vodka varieties have become numerous and may be found commonly in stores in the U.S.A.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thespiritsbusiness.com/2015/04/flavoured-vodka-not-dead-but-market-evolving/|title=Flavoured Vodka Market not Dead but Evolving|last=|first=|date=2015|website=The Spirits Business|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=26 March 2018}}</ref>
===Alcohol sponsorship in sport=== Sport has been suggested to be one of the primary, if not the dominant, medium for the promotion of alcohol and drinking to the general population with the majority of advertising spend an advertising placement occurring in sport.<ref>[http://www.camy.org/bin/s/a/Alcohol_Advertising_on_Sports_Television.pdf "Alcohol Advertising on Sports Television 2001 to 2003"]. Center on Alcohol Marketing and Youth 2004. . {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101011143559/http://www.camy.org/bin/s/a/Alcohol_Advertising_on_Sports_Television.pdf |date=October 11, 2010 }}</ref> Work from New Zealand<ref>O'Brien K, and Kypri K. Alcohol industry sponsorship of sport and hazardous drinking among New Zealand sportspeople. Addiction 2008; 103(12): 1961-6.</ref> and Australia<ref>O’Brien K.S., Miller P.G., Kolt G.S., Martens M.P., Webber A. Alcohol industry and non-alcohol industry sponsorship of sportspeople and drinking. Alcohol and Alcoholism 2011; 46: 210-13.</ref> shows that sponsorship of sports participants or athletes is associated with more hazardous drinking, with calls from the UK, Australia, and New Zealand, for bans on alcohol industry sponsorship and advertising in sport.
==See also== *[[Group Against Liquor Advertising]] (GALA) (in New Zealand) *[[The War on Drugs (band)|The War on Drugs]] - prominent beer commercial rock-band
