Times of India|work=The Times of India|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref> |- | 2 || {{IND}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1971|12|06}} |- | 3 || {{flag|Polish People's Republic|name=Poland}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|12}} |- | 4 || {{flag|People's Republic of Bulgaria|name=Bulgaria}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|12}} |- | 5 || {{flagdeco|Burma|1974}} [[Burmese Way to Socialism|Burma]] || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|13}} |- | 6 || {{flag|Kingdom of Nepal|name=Nepal}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|16}} |- | 7 || {{BRB}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|20}} |- | 8 || {{YUG}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|22}} |- | 9 || {{TON}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|25}} |- | 10 || {{USSR}}|| {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|26}} |- | 11 || {{flag|Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|name=Czechoslovakia}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|26}} |- | 12 || {{CYP}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|26}} |- | 13 || {{flagcountry|HPR}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|26}} |- | 14 || {{AUS}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|26}} |- | 15 || {{FJI}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|26}} |- | 16 || {{NZL}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|01|26}} |- | 17 || {{SEN}} || {{dts|format=dmy|1972|02|01}} |- | 18 || {{GBR}} || 4 February 1972 |- | 19 || {{FRG}} || 4 February 1972 |- | 20 ||{{FIN}} || 4 February 1972 |- | 21 ||{{DEN}} || 4 February 1972 |- | 22 ||{{SWE}} || 4 February 1972 |- | 23 ||{{NOR}} || 4 February 1972 |- | 24 ||{{ISL}} || 4 February 1972 |- | 25 ||{{ISR}} || 4 February 1972 |- | 26 || {{flag|Japan|1870}} || 8 February 1972 |- | 27 || {{LUX}} || 11 February 1972 |- | 28 || {{NLD}} || 11 February 1972 |- | 29 || {{BEL}}|| 11 February 1972 |- | 30 || {{IRL}} || 11 February 1972 |- | 31 || {{ITA}} || 12 February 1972 |- | 32 || {{FRA}} || 14 February 1972 |- | 33 || {{CAN}} || 14 February 1972 |- | 34 || {{SIN}}|| 16 February 1972 |- | 35 || {{flagdeco|MUS}} [[Mauritius (1968–1992)|Mauritius]] || 20 February 1972 |- | 36 || {{USA}} || 4 April 1972 |}

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2014}} {{good article}} {{Infobox clothing item | image_file = Lady Gaga meat dress.jpg | designer = [[Franc Fernandez]] | year = 2010 | material = Raw [[flank steak]] | on_display_at = [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] |caption=Gaga wearing the meat dress at the [[2010 MTV Video Music Awards]]}}
At the [[2010 MTV Video Music Awards]], American singer [[Lady Gaga]] wore a dress made of raw [[beef]], which was commonly referred to by the media as the '''meat dress'''.<ref name="mtvdesigner"/><ref name="guardianangers"/><ref name="designerhuffington"/> Designed by [[Franc Fernandez]] and styled by [[Nicola Formichetti]], the dress was condemned by animal rights groups, and named by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' as the top fashion statement of 2010.
The press speculated on the originality of the meat dress idea, with comparisons made to similar images found in contemporary art and popular culture. As with her other dresses, it was archived, but went on display in 2011 at the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] after being preserved by [[taxidermist]]s as a type of [[jerky]]. Gaga explained following the awards ceremony that the dress was a statement about one's need to fight for what one believes in, and highlighted her distaste for the US military's [[Don't ask, don't tell|don't-ask-don't-tell]] policy.
==Background== Gaga was the most nominated artist at 2010's Video Music Awards with a record thirteen nominations, including two nods for [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]] (the first female artist to achieve this feat).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1644956/lady-gaga-eminem-top-vma-nominations/|title=Lady Gaga, Eminem Top VMA Nominations|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|date=August 3, 2010|publisher=MTV News|accessdate=May 20, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505132012/http://www.mtv.com/news/1644956/lady-gaga-eminem-top-vma-nominations/|archivedate=May 5, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> She arrived in an [[Alexander McQueen]] dress and changed into a [[Giorgio Armani]] number before donning her third and final outfit of the evening: a dress, hat, boots, and purse made of raw meat. Gaga wore the meat dress to accept her Video of the Year trophy for "[[Bad Romance]]"; as she accepted the award from presenter [[Cher]], she joked, "I never thought I'd be asking Cher to hold my meat purse."<ref name="ganz">{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/stop-the-presses/meet-the-mystery-meat-dress-lady-gaga-explains-rare-vmas-outfit.html|title=Meet the Mystery Meat Dress: Lady Gaga Explains Rare VMAs Outfit|last=Ganz|first=Caryn|date=September 12, 2010|archivedate=December 25, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111225012039/http://music.yahoo.com/blogs/stop-the-presses/meet-the-mystery-meat-dress-lady-gaga-explains-rare-vmas-outfit.html|publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]|accessdate=May 20, 2013}}</ref> Gaga continued to wear the dress after the awards show for press photos and an interview on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]''.<ref name=mtvdesigner/> Gaga explained her interpretation of the dress to DeGeneres, stating, "If we don’t stand up for what we believe in and if we don’t fight for our rights[,] pretty soon we’re going to have as much rights as the meat on our bones."<ref name="marquee">{{cite web|url=http://marquee.blogs.cnn.com/2010/09/14/so-about-lady-gagas-meat-dress/|title=So about Lady Gaga's meat dress...|date=September 14, 2010|publisher=CNN.com Blogs|accessdate=May 20, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102053246/http://www.mtv.com/news/1647701/lady-gaga-talks-vma-meat-suit-with-ellen-degeneres/|archivedate=November 2, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> "Now, I love Lady Gaga, but as someone who also loves animals, it was really difficult for me to sit next to Lady Gaga while she was wearing that outfit," DeGeneres, who is [[vegan]], later wrote. "But it did make me ask myself, what's the difference between her outfit and an outfit made of leather?"<ref name="marquee"/>
==Design== [[File:Lady Gaga Americano Manchester cropped.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Gaga wearing a faux-meat dress during the [[Born This Way Ball]] tour.]] Fernandez was approached by fellow designer and stylist Formichetti to produce the dress, with it planned out over the course of a week,<ref name=mtvdesigner/> Formichetti having styled the look.<ref name="real?" /> The dress was asymmetrical, with a cowled–neck.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite news|last=Topping|first=Alexandra|title=Lady Gaga's meat dress angers animal rights groups|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/sep/13/lady-gaga-meat-dress-vmas|accessdate=May 14, 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130916224716/http://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/sep/13/lady-gaga-meat-dress-vmas|archivedate=September 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Fernandez specifically chose cuts to ensure that the dress kept well.<ref name=mtvdesigner>{{cite web|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|title=Lady Gaga Meat Dress Designer Tells How To Re-Create His VMA Look|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1647978/lady-gaga-meat-dress-designer-tells-how-to-re-create-his-vma-look/|accessdate=May 14, 2011|publisher=[[MTV News]]|date=September 16, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140707001916/http://www.mtv.com/news/1647978/lady-gaga-meat-dress-designer-tells-how-to-re-create-his-vma-look/|archivedate=July 7, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Flank steak]] was chosen as the material to use,<ref name=designerhuffington>{{cite web|last=Padilla|first=Max|title=Lady Gaga Meat Dress Designer's Lips Are Zipped About Animal Rights|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/max-padilla/lady-gaga-meat-dress-franc-fernandez_b_737206.html|accessdate=May 14, 2011|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=September 24, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909123157/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/max-padilla/lady-gaga-meat-dress-franc-fernandez_b_737206.html|archivedate=September 9, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> with the meat coming from his family [[butcher]].<ref name="real?" /> The dress required Gaga to be stitched into the outfit backstage.<ref name=designerqa />
Fernandez said of his design, "I knew the dress would be one of other amazing pieces Gaga wore that night. It's very well made and looked great on her, on and off camera. We didn't get a chance to have a fitting. The only time she had it on was for the VMAs. Only when I saw it in the monitor did I know it would be big."<ref name=designerhuffington />
Fernandez reporting Gaga's opinion in an interview said that Gaga herself said it smelled good, because it smelled like meat.<ref name=mtvdesigner /> The designer talked of what was to happen to the dress after the awards show, "The dress will be put in an archive with all of her dresses. The Gaga Archives, I suppose. It won't last, that's the beauty of it. When it is brought out again, hopefully it will be in a retrospective, and it will be a different dress, which is the best thing. I like the idea of it changing and evolving into something else".<ref name=mtvdesigner /> He later explained that the dress would be preserved and made into a type of [[jerky (food)|jerky]] before being archived.<ref name=jerky>{{cite web|last=Gornstein|first=Leslie|title=Did anyone ever eat Lady Gaga's meat dress?|url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/39311642/ns/today-entertainment/t/did-anyone-ever-eat-lady-gagas-meat-dress/|accessdate=May 14, 2011|publisher=[[E!]]|date=September 22, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325022326/http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/39311642/ns/today-entertainment/t/did-anyone-ever-eat-lady-gagas-meat-dress|archivedate=March 25, 2012}}</ref>
The [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] paid $6,000 to taxidermist Sergio Vigilato to preserve the dress. It had been frozen following the two television appearances, although Vigilato discovered signs of decomposition on the dress which had occurred prior to it being frozen, and noted it was emitting an odor once it was defrosted. It was treated with bleach, [[formaldehyde]] and detergent to kill any bacteria which had formed, and was reconditioned by being dyed dark red once it was preserved so to give it the same appearance as when first worn. However, after the preservation there were several pieces of beef left over and not included in the reworked dress.<ref name=preserves>{{cite web|last=Pool |first=Bob |title=Taxidermist preserves Lady Gaga's meat dress for posterity |url=https://vancouversun.com/travel/Taxidermist+preserves+Lady+Gaga+meat+dress+posterity/5145206/story.html |accessdate=July 31, 2011 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=July 22, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726020721/http://www.vancouversun.com/travel/Taxidermist%2Bpreserves%2BLady%2BGaga%2Bmeat%2Bdress%2Bposterity/5145206/story.html |archivedate=July 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Gaga wore a faux-meat dress while performing the songs "[[Americano (song)|Americano]]" and "[[Poker Face (Lady Gaga song)|Poker Face]]" during her [[Born This Way Ball]] tour.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dumaual|first=Miguel|title=Review: Lady Gaga's 'Born This Way Ball'|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/lifestyle/05/23/12/review-lady-gagas-born-way-ball|publisher=[[ABS-CBN News and Current Affairs|ABS-CBN]]|accessdate=June 9, 2012|date=May 23, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160827132931/http://news.abs-cbn.com/lifestyle/05/23/12/review-lady-gagas-born-way-ball|archivedate=August 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Influence== [[File:Rock-and-roll-hall-of-fame-sunset.jpg|thumb|The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, where the meat dress went on display in 2011|alt=An extended glass pyramid in front of a tall gray building with strangely shaped outcroppings]] Previously, she had worn a bikini made of meat on the front cover of the Japanese edition of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/gossip/flesh-lady-gaga-dons-raw-meat-cover-vogue-hommes-japan-article-1.438875|work=New York Daily News|title=In the flesh: Lady Gaga dons raw meat on cover of Vogue Hommes Japan|author=Cristina Everett|date=7 September 2010}}</ref> It was originally worn by Gaga at the [[2010 MTV Video Music Awards]] to accept her award for [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]].<ref name="real?" /> Although it was Gaga's third costume change of the evening, the meat dress was immediately described as "most outrageous fashion moment" of the evening.<ref name="real?">{{cite web|last=Clott|first=Sharon|title=Was Lady Gaga's VMA Meat Dress Real?|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2513132/2010-vmas-was-lady-gagas-meat-dress-real/|accessdate=May 14, 2011|publisher=MTV News|date=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427152223/http://www.mtv.com/news/2513132/2010-vmas-was-lady-gagas-meat-dress-real/|archivedate=April 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Fernandez credits the dress with an upturn in his career, saying, "I feel like I have a voice now as an artist and as a designer".<ref name=designerqa>{{cite web|last=Vazquez|first=Anna|title=Lady Gaga Meat Dress Designer Franc Fernandez Q&A|url=http://main.stylelist.com/2011/03/09/lady-gaga-meat-dress-designer-franc-fernandez/|accessdate=May 14, 2011|newspaper=Stylelist|publisher=[[AOL]]|date=March 9, 2010|archivedate=September 10, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110910080436/http://main.stylelist.com/2011/03/09/lady-gaga-meat-dress-designer-franc-fernandez/}}</ref> He had previously created items for Gaga, including a costume for her music video for "[[Bad Romance]]".<ref>[http://francfernandez.blogspot.ca/2009/11/lady-gaga-bad-romance-video.html Franc Fernandez]</ref> He went on to create a hat that Gaga wore to the [[53rd Grammy Awards]] in February 2011.<ref name=designerqa/>
The dress went on display at the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum]] in 2011 as part of an exhibition entitled "Women Who Rock: Vision, Passion, Power".<ref name=exhibit2011>{{cite web|last=Mapes|first=Jill|title=Women Who Rock' Exhibit Opens, Features Lady Gaga's Meat Dress|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/471588/women-who-rock-exhibit-opens-features-lady-gagas-meat-dress|accessdate=May 14, 2011|newspaper=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=May 13, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311120556/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/471588/women-who-rock-exhibit-opens-features-lady-gagas-meat-dress|archivedate=March 11, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
A poll by website MyCelebrityFashion.co.uk placed the dress as the most iconic outfit of 2010, beating [[Kate Middleton]]'s [[Engagement announcement dress of Kate Middleton|engagement dress]] into second place.<ref name=iconic>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Ann|title=Lady Gaga's meat dress 'most iconic' of 2010|url=http://metro.co.uk/2010/12/16/lady-gagas-meat-dress-most-iconic-of-2010-613627/|accessdate=May 14, 2011|newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|location=London|date=December 16, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004233749/http://metro.co.uk/2010/12/16/lady-gagas-meat-dress-most-iconic-of-2010-613627/|archivedate=October 4, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> In summing up 2010 through a series of lists, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' voted the meat dress as its top fashion statement of 2010.<ref name=top10time>{{cite web|title=The Top 10 Everything of 2010 |url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0,29569,2035319,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820065952/http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/completelist/0%2C29569%2C2035319%2C00.html |deadurl=no |archivedate=August 20, 2016 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=May 14, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref name=indytopten>{{cite web|title=Lady Gaga's meat dress 'No. 1' fashion statement of 2010|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/lady-gagas-meat-dress-no-1-fashion-statement-of-2010-2163512.html|accessdate=May 14, 2011|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|location=London|date=December 17, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101220145200/http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/fashion/lady-gagas-meat-dress-no-1-fashion-statement-of-2010-2163512.html|archivedate=December 20, 2010}}</ref>
When [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] did a parody of Gaga's "[[Born This Way (song)|Born This Way]]", titled "[[Perform This Way]]", he included a lyrical reference to the meat dress ("I strap prime rib to my feet / Cover myself with raw meat / I'll bet you've never seen a skirt steak worn this way") and had a dancer dressed in a similar outfit in the music video.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-31749_162-20072941-10391698.html|title=Weird Al Yankovic lampoons Lady Gaga in 'Perform This Way'|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=June 21, 2011|accessdate=June 21, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110623044958/http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-31749_162-20072941-10391698.html|archivedate=June 23, 2011}}</ref>
==Reception== Following the VMAs, media outlets attempted to analyse the meaning of the dress with suggestions by [[BBC News]] ranging from [[anti-fashion]], to [[feminism]], aging and decay, and society's attitude towards meat. Chef [[Fergus Henderson]] explained this meat attitude as "People often don't want meat to look like meat. They want it to be neatly wrapped in plastic from a supermarket."<ref name=interpret>{{cite news|last=Winterman|first=Denise|last2=Kelly|first2=Jon|title=Five interpretations of Lady Gaga's meat dress|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-11297832|accessdate=May 14, 2011|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=September 14, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100915042148/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-11297832|archivedate=September 15, 2010|df=mdy-all|work=BBC News}}</ref> [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]] (PETA) condemned the dress, releasing a statement that said "wearing a dress made from cuts of dead cows is offensive enough to bring comment, but someone should whisper in her ear that more people are upset by butchery than are impressed by it."<ref name=meattelegraph>{{cite news|last=Roberts|first=Laura|title=Lady Gaga's meat dress divides opinion|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/8001267/Lady-Gagas-meat-dress-divides-opinion.html|accessdate=May 14, 2011|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=September 14, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100914221630/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/8001267/Lady-Gagas-meat-dress-divides-opinion.html|archivedate=September 14, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=peta>{{cite web|last=Newkirk|first=Ingrid E.|title=Lady Gaga's Meat Dress|url=http://www.peta.org/blog/lady-gagas-meat-dress/|date=September 13, 2010|publisher=[[PETA]]|accessdate=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archivedate=July 24, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160724024859/http://www.peta.org/blog/lady-gagas-meat-dress/}}</ref> The Vegetarian Society also condemned the dress, releasing a statement that said "No matter how beautifully it is presented, flesh from a tortured animal is flesh from a tortured animal. Enough animals die for food and they should not be killed for stunts like this."<ref name=beatles>{{cite news|last=Bloxham|first=Andy|title=Lady Gaga's meat dress link to the Beatles|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/8003533/Lady-Gagas-meat-dress-link-to-the-Beatles.html|accessdate=July 31, 2011|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|date=September 15, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110204133029/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/8003533/Lady-Gagas-meat-dress-link-to-the-Beatles.html|archivedate=February 4, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Another controversy surrounding the dress was the question of its originality. Brooks Barnes of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that the dress was "derived" from ''Incarnation'', a painting of a white-haired girl wearing a meat dress by artist [[Mark Ryden]].<ref name=ryden>{{cite news|last=Barnes|first=Brooks|title=Mark Ryden: Drawing a Dividing Line|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/18/fashion/mark-ryden-drawing-a-dividing-line.html|accessdate=April 6, 2016|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=May 16, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160317040954/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/18/fashion/mark-ryden-drawing-a-dividing-line.html|archivedate=March 17, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=mtv>{{cite web|last=Clott|first=Sharon|title=Does Lady Gaga's Meat Dress Remind You Of Mark Ryden's Paintings?|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2513127/lady-gaga-meat-dress-vmas-2010-mark-ryden/|accessdate=April 6, 2016|publisher=MTV News|date=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160415122655/http://www.mtv.com/news/2513127/lady-gaga-meat-dress-vmas-2010-mark-ryden/|archivedate=April 15, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Sharon Clott of MTV also noted the similarity between Gaga's dress and Ryden's painting.<ref name=mtv/> Ryden was reportedly upset that Gaga did not acknowledge that she took inspiration from his work.<ref name=ryden/> Some in the art and fashion press remarked on the dress' similarity to [[Vanitas: Flesh Dress for an Albino Anorectic]], a meat dress made by Canadian sculptor [[Jana Sterbak]] in 1987 exhibited to considerable controversy at the National Gallery of Canada in 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2010/09/lady-gaga-meat-dress-recycled.html|work=Los Angeles Times|title=Lady Gaga, meat Jana Sterbak|date=September 13, 2010|accessdate=September 16, 2016|first=Christopher|last=Knight|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160820204838/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2010/09/lady-gaga-meat-dress-recycled.html|archivedate=August 20, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2010-09-16/lady-gaga-s-fleshy-outfit-echoes-artistic-maggots-seafood-martin-gayford|title=Lady Gaga's Fleshy Outfit Echoes Artistic Lobsters, Maggots|accessdate=September 16, 2016|date=September 17, 2010|first=Martin|last=Gayford|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917081029/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2010-09-16/lady-gaga-s-fleshy-outfit-echoes-artistic-maggots-seafood-martin-gayford|archivedate=September 17, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thegloss.com/culture/lady-gagas-meat-dress-and-the-question-of-authenticity/|title=Lady Gaga's Meat Dress and the Question of Authenticity|date=September 13, 2010|first=Ashley|last=Seashore|work=TheGloss|archivedate=December 2, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202160715/http://thegloss.com/culture/lady-gagas-meat-dress-and-the-question-of-authenticity/|accessdate=September 16, 2016}}</ref> Karen Rosenberg from ''The New York Times'' compared the dress to a series of photographs of [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]] posing with sides of beef attached to his torso like wings in 1952,<ref>{{cite news|last=Rosenberg|first=Karen|title=Two Meaty Visions of Flesh and Blood|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/13/arts/design/soutinebacon-at-helly-nahmad-gallery-review.html|accessdate=May 14, 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 12, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516165046/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/13/arts/design/soutinebacon-at-helly-nahmad-gallery-review.html|archivedate=May 16, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> while ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' compared the dress to the original cover of [[The Beatles]]' 1966 album ''[[Yesterday and Today]]'', and noted its similarity to the cover of the November 1983 [[The Undertones]] album ''All Wrapped Up'', which showed a female model wearing a dress and gloves made of cuts of meat (mostly bacon) held in place with plastic wrap and a sausage necklace.<ref name=beatles /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-24942186|publisher=BBC News|title=Dressed to grill: From The Undertones to Lady Gaga|date=November 15, 2013|accessdate=September 16, 2016|first=Chris|last=Heard|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315101246/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-24942186|archivedate=March 15, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Architects [[Diller Scofidio + Renfro]] had also designed a meat dress in 2006.<ref name=guardianangers>{{cite web|title=Music Piracy: Lady Gaga Is To Blame|url=http://www.lovelyish.com/2011/07/09/music-piracy-artists-like-lady-gaga-are-to-blame/|accessdate=February 25, 2012|date=July 9, 2011|publisher=Lovelyish.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006122616/http://www.lovelyish.com/2011/07/09/music-piracy-artists-like-lady-gaga-are-to-blame/|archivedate=October 6, 2013}}</ref> An earlier example of a garment made from meat stitched together in the same way as the Lady Gaga meat dress was worn at the [[Slade School of Art]] postgraduate degree exhibition opening in London, England in July 1979, when [[performance artist]] Robert Connolly wore a two-piece suit made of slices of [[salami]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2010/sep/20/salami-style|title=Letters: Salami style|accessdate=September 16, 2016|date=September 20, 2010|newspaper=The Guardian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160927153640/https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2010/sep/20/salami-style|archivedate=September 27, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Some media sources proposed that the dress could be interpreted as anti-[[vegan]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Is Lady Gaga's Meat Couture an Anti-Vegan Statement?|url=https://www.good.is/articles/is-lady-gaga-s-meat-couture-an-anti-vegan-statement|work=[[Good (magazine)|Good]]|date=September 13, 2010|accessdate=September 16, 2016|first=Alissa|last=Walker|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917085052/https://www.good.is/articles/is-lady-gaga-s-meat-couture-an-anti-vegan-statement|archivedate=September 17, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Vegetarian singer [[Morrissey]] stated that he felt the dress was acceptable as long as it was a social or political statement, and not just a "loony idea",<ref name=morrisseydress>{{cite news|last=Deacon|first=Michael|title=Morrissey on... Lady Gaga and modern pop|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/8579607/Morrissey-on...-Lady-Gaga-and-modern-pop.html|accessdate=June 28, 2011|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=June 17, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110620192452/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/8579607/Morrissey-on...-Lady-Gaga-and-modern-pop.html|archivedate=June 20, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> pointing out that artist [[Linder Sterling]] had previously worn a meat dress in 1982 to protest against what she believed to be the perception of women by men.<ref name=morrisseydress/> [[Ellen DeGeneres]] presented Gaga with a [[bikini]] made of vegetables when the singer appeared on her talk show, and the singer used the platform to respond to the controversy surrounding the dress saying, "... it has many interpretations. For me this evening, if we don't stand up for what we believe in and if we don't fight for our rights pretty soon, we're going to have as much rights as the meat on our own bones. And, I am not a piece of meat."<ref name=meattelegraph/> She explained further that she was also using the dress to highlight her distaste for the US military's "[[don't ask, don't tell]]" policy.<ref name=mtvtalks>{{cite web|last=Kaufman|first=Gil|title=Lady Gaga Talks VMA Meat Suit With Ellen DeGeneres|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1647701/lady-gaga-talks-vma-meat-suit-with-ellen-degeneres/|publisher=MTV News|accessdate=November 28, 2011|date=September 13, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141102053246/http://www.mtv.com/news/1647701/lady-gaga-talks-vma-meat-suit-with-ellen-degeneres/|archivedate=November 2, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==Further reading== {{commons category}} *{{cite journal |last1=Smith |first1=Heather |date=March 2011 |title=Behind the Meat Dress: There are people sewing the meat dress |journal=[[Meatpaper]] |issue=14 |url=http://www.meatpaper.com/articles/2011/mp_fourteen_gaga.html | accessdate=September 16, 2016|deadurl=no |archivedate= March 11, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110311092524/http://meatpaper.com/articles/2011/mp_fourteen_gaga.html}}

{{Orphan|date=January 2013}} '''Legends – voices of rock''' is a constellation where several legendary lead singers perform their biggest hits. Constellation varies, included artists{{cite web|url=http://www.stahl.fi/?page=Artists&article=271|title=LEGENDS of ROCK|website=www.stahl.fi}} are Grammy award-winning and platinum selling stars like [[Bobby Kimball]]{{cite web |url=http://bobbykimball.com/tourdates.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110012613/http://www.bobbykimball.com/tourdates.htm |archivedate=2012-11-10 |df= }} (original lead singer of [[Toto (band)|Toto]]), [[Steve Augeri]]{{cite web|url=http://0dayrockz.blogspot.se/2012/05/steve-augeri-photograph-3-2012.html|title=STEVE AUGERI - Photograph +3 (2012)|website=0dayrockz.blogspot.se}} (ex [[Journey (band)|Journey]]), [[Joe Lynn Turner]]{{cite web|url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/joe-lynn-turner-steve-augeri-taking-part-in-legends-voices-of-rock-tour/|title=JOE LYNN TURNER, STEVE AUGERI Taking Part In 'Legends: Voices Of Rock' Tour|first=|last=Blabbermouth|date=18 May 2012|website=BLABBERMOUTH.NET}} (ex [[Rainbow (English band)|Rainbow]], [[Deep Purple]]), [[Bill Champlin]]{{cite web|url=http://www.tv4play.se/program/nyhetsmorgon?title=legends_you_re_not_alone&video_id=2213319|title=Legends – You’re not alone|publisher=|access-date=2012-10-16|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224112326/http://www.tv4play.se/program/nyhetsmorgon?title=legends_you_re_not_alone&video_id=2213319#|archive-date=2013-12-24|dead-url=yes|df=}} (formerly of [[Chicago (band)|Chicago]]), [[Fergie Frederiksen]]{{cite web|url=http://www.fergiefrederiksen.com/?p=663|title=Videos from Swedish TV4 - Fergie Frederiksen|website=www.fergiefrederiksen.com}} (ex [[Toto (band)|Toto]]), [[Bruce Kulick]]{{Cite web |url=http://legends-vor.com/legends-voices-of-rock/bruce-kulick/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-10-14 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130127213432/http://legends-vor.com/legends-voices-of-rock/bruce-kulick/# |archive-date=2013-01-27 |dead-url=yes |df= }} (ex [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]]), [[Robin Beck]] and more. First Legends tour was Japan,{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Hmx7PgJryrM|title=LEGENDS Voices Of Rock promo|first=|last=Tommy Denander|date=26 June 2012|publisher=|via=YouTube}} June 2012, with shows in Nagoya,{{cite web|url=http://www.creativeman.co.jp/blog/13231/|title=NEWS - CREATIVEMAN PRODUCTIONS - Part 13231|website=CREATIVEMAN PRODUCTIONS}} Osaka{{cite web|url=http://www.creativeman.co.jp/blog/13298/|title=NEWS - CREATIVEMAN PRODUCTIONS - Part 13298|website=CREATIVEMAN PRODUCTIONS}} and Tokyo.{{cite web|url=http://www.creativeman.co.jp/blog/13326/|title=NEWS - CREATIVEMAN PRODUCTIONS - Part 13326|website=CREATIVEMAN PRODUCTIONS}} The Legends project was presented to the Swedish audience live on national TV4.{{cite web |url=http://www.tv4play.se/program/nyhetsmorgon?title=legends_om_turnen_som_forenat_storheter_inom_rock&video_id=2213320 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224111846/http://www.tv4play.se/program/nyhetsmorgon?title=legends_om_turnen_som_forenat_storheter_inom_rock&video_id=2213320 |archivedate=2013-12-24 |df= }} Behind the project are the two well-known Swedish guitar players, Tommy Denander and Sayit Dölen.
[[Tommy Denander]] is a Grammy award nominated world-famous guitarist. He has played on more than 2000 albums with superstars like [[Michael Jackson]], [[Alice Cooper]], [[Paul Stanley]], [[Ricky Martin]], [[Celine Dion]], [[Peter Cetera]], [[BB King]], [[Carlos Santana]] and many more.
Sayit Dölen has a long career of studio and live work with stars like [[Enrique Iglesias]], [[Yngwie Malmsteen]], [[Jimi Jamison]], [[Bobby Kimball]], [[Katie Melua]] and many more. Top musicians are handpicked for the Legends band{{cite web|url=http://www.andyflash.se/spinechained/legends12.htm|title=Legends-Voices Of Rock 2012|website=www.andyflash.se}} in a serious effort to play the hits true to the originals. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://legends-vor.com/ Legends official website] broken link since 2014 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140328163031/http://www.legends-vor.com/ Legends official website] * [http://bobbykimball.com/ Bobby Kimball official website] * [http://www.steveaugeri.com/ Steve Augeri official website] * [http://www.joelynnturner.com/ Joe Lynn Turner official website] * [http://www.billchamplin.net/ Bill Champlin official website] * [http://www.fergiefrederiksen.com/ Fergie Frederiksen official website] * [http://www.kulick.net/ Bruce Kulick official website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Legends - voices of rock}} [[Category:Swedish music television series]] [[Category:Concert tours]] [[Category:Swedish rock music groups]]

Lydia Kamakaʻeha ''(name after baptism)'' |house=[[House of Kalākaua|Kalākaua]] |father=[[Kapaakea|Caesar Kapaʻakea]]. ''[[Hānai]]'' adoptive father; [[Abner Pākī]] |mother=[[Keohokālole|Analea Keohokālole]]. ''Hānai'' adoptive mother; [[Laura Kōnia]] |birth_date={{Birth date|1838|9|2}} |birth_place=[[Honolulu]], [[Oahu|Oʻahu]], [[Kingdom of Hawaii]] |death_date={{Death date and age|1917|11|11|1838|9|2}} |death_place=[[Honolulu]], [[Oahu|Oʻahu]], [[Territory of Hawaii]] |place of burial=[[Royal Mausoleum of Hawaii|Mauna ʻAla Royal Mausoleum]] |burial_date=November 18, 1917 |signature=Liliuokalani's signature (Anti-Annexation Protest Documents, June 17, 1897, Washington D C).svg |religion=[[Protestantism]] [[#Religious beliefs|(more...)]] |}} '''Liliʻuokalani''' ({{IPA-haw|liˌliʔuokəˈlɐni}}; born '''Lydia Liliʻu Loloku Walania Kamakaʻeha'''; September 2, 1838 – November 11, 1917) was the first [[queen regnant]] and the last sovereign monarch of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii|Kingdom of Hawaiʻi]], ruling from January 29, 1891, until the [[overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii|overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaiʻi]] on January 17, 1893. The composer of "[[Aloha ʻOe]]" and numerous other works, she wrote her autobiography ''[[Hawaii's Story by Hawaii's Queen|Hawaiʻi's Story by Hawaiʻi's Queen]]'' during her imprisonment following the overthrow. Liliʻuokalani was born on September 2, 1838, in [[Honolulu]], on the island of [[Oahu|Oʻahu]]. While her natural parents were [[Keohokālole|Analea Keohokālole]] and [[Kapaakea|Caesar Kapaʻakea]], she was ''[[hānai]]'' (informally adopted) at birth by [[Pākī|Abner Pākī]] and [[Kōnia|Laura Kōnia]] and raised with their daughter [[Bernice Pauahi Bishop]]. Baptized as a Christian and educated at the [[Royal School (Hawaii)|Royal School]], she and her siblings and cousins were proclaimed eligible for the throne by King [[Kamehameha III]]. She was married to American-born [[John Owen Dominis]], who later became the [[Governor of Oahu|Governor of Oʻahu]]. The couple had no biological children but adopted several. After the accession of her brother [[Kalākaua|David Kalākaua]] to the throne in 1874, she and her siblings were given Western style titles of Prince and Princess. In 1877, after her younger brother [[Leleiohoku II]]'s death, she was proclaimed as heir apparent to the throne. During the [[Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria|Golden Jubilee]] of [[Queen Victoria]], she represented her brother as an official envoy to the United Kingdom. Liliʻuokalani ascended to the throne on January 29, 1891, nine days after her brother's death. During her reign, she attempted to draft a [[Proposed 1893 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii|new constitution]] which would restore the power of the monarchy and the voting rights of the economically disenfranchised. Threatened by her attempts to abrogate the [[Bayonet Constitution]], pro-American elements in Hawaiʻi [[Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii|overthrew]] the monarchy on January 17, 1893. The overthrow was bolstered by the landing of US Marines under [[John L. Stevens]] to protect American interests, which rendered the monarchy unable to protect itself. The coup d'état established the [[Republic of Hawaii|Republic of Hawaiʻi]], but the ultimate goal was the annexation of the islands to the United States, which was temporarily blocked by President [[Grover Cleveland]]. After an [[1895 Counter-revolution in Hawaii|unsuccessful uprising to restore the monarchy]], the oligarchical government placed the former queen under house arrest at the [[ʻIolani Palace]]. On January 24, 1895, Liliʻuokalani was forced to abdicate the Hawaiian throne, officially ending the deposed monarchy. Attempts were made to restore the monarchy and [[Opposition to the overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii|oppose annexation]], but with the outbreak of the [[Spanish–American War]], the United States [[Annexation of Hawaii|annexed Hawaiʻi]]. Living out the remainder of her later life as a private citizen, Liliʻuokalani [[Death and funeral of Liliuokalani|died]] at her residence, [[Washington Place]], in Honolulu on November 11, 1917. == Early life == Liliʻuokalani was born Lydia Liliʻu Loloku Walania Kamakaʻeha{{#tag:ref|Other source gives her the additional name of "Wewehi" which has no translation in relation to her birth.{{sfn|Morris|1993|page=x}}|group=note}} on September 2, 1838, to the Analea Keohokālole and Caesar Kapaʻakea. She was born in the large grass hut of her maternal grandfather, [[Aikanaka (father of Keohokālole)|ʻAikanaka]], at the base of [[Punchbowl Crater]] in [[Honolulu]] on the island of [[Oahu|Oʻahu]].{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=1–4}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|page=33}}{{#tag:ref|The area was traditionally referred to as Mana, Manamana, Honolulu and later became the site of [[The Queen's Medical Center|The Queen's Hospital]].{{harvnb|Kanahele|1999|page=105}}; {{cite news|title=La Hanau o ke Kama Aliiwahine Liliu|newspaper=Ka Nupepa Kuokoa|location=Honolulu|date=September 4, 1875|volume=XIV|issue=36|page=2|url=http://nupepa.org/gsdl2.5/cgi-bin/nupepa?e=d-0nupepa--00-0-0--010---4----text-prev--0-1l--1haw-Zz-1--en-20-about--20-00031-0000utfZz-8-00-0003-1-0000utfZz-8-00&a=d&cl=CL1.24.15&d=HASHc325b95aa0f37c0b812dee.2|accessdate=September 26, 2016}}|group=note}} According to Hawaiian custom, she was named after an event linked to her birth. At the time she was born, ''[[Kuhina Nui]]'' (regent) [[Kīnaʻu|Elizabeth Kīnaʻu]] had developed an eye infection. She named the child using the words; ''liliʻu'' (smarting), ''loloku'' (tearful), ''walania'' (a burning pain) and ''kamakaʻeha'' (sore eyes).{{sfn|Pukui|Elbert|1986|pages=38, 206, 211. 224 ,381}}{{harvnb|Haley|2014|page=232}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|page=36}}; {{harvnb|Siler|2012|page=32}} Upon her baptism by Reverend Levi Chamberlain, she was given the Christian name Lydia.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|page=40}}; {{harvnb|Cooke|Cooke|1937|page=20}} [[File:Lydia Kamakaeha.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Liliʻuokalani in her youth, c. 1853]] Her family were of the [[aliʻi]] class of the Hawaiian nobility and were collateral relations of the reigning [[House of Kamehameha]], sharing common descent from the 18th-century ''aliʻi nui'' (supreme monarch) [[Keaweʻīkekahialiʻiokamoku]]. From her biological parents, she descended from [[Keaweaheulu]] and [[Kameʻeiamoku]], two of the five royal counselors of [[Kamehameha I]] during his conquest of the [[Kingdom of Hawaii]]. Kameʻeiamoku, the grandfather of both her mother and father, was depicted, along with his royal twin Kamanawa, on the Hawaiian coat of arms.{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=1–2, 104–105, 399–409}}; {{harvnb|Pratt|1920|pages=34–36}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pp=33–36}}; {{harvnb|Haley|2014|page=96}}; {{harvnb|Gregg|1982|pages=316–317, 528, 571, 581}} Liliʻuokalani referred to her family line as the "Keawe-a-Heulu line" after her mother's line.{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pp=104–105}}; {{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|page=262}}; {{harvnb|Osorio|2002|p=201}}; {{harvnb|Van Dyke|2008|p=96}} The third surviving child of a large family, her biological siblings included: [[James Kaliokalani]], [[Kalākaua|David Kalākaua]], [[Anna Kaiulani|Anna Kaʻiulani]], [[Kaiminaauao|Kaʻiminaʻauao]], [[Likelike|Miriam Likelike]] and [[Leleiohoku II|William Pitt Leleiohoku II]].{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|page=399}} She and her siblings were ''[[hānai]]'' (informally adopted) to other family members. The Hawaiian custom of ''hānai'' is an informal form of adoption between extended families practiced by Hawaiian royals and commoners alike.{{sfn|Kanahele|1999|pages=1–4}}{{sfn|King|Roth|2006|page=15}} She was given at birth to Abner Pākī and his wife Laura Kōnia and raised with their daughter [[Bernice Pauahi]].{{sfn|Hodges|1918|page=13}}{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=1–4}} In 1842, at the age of four, she began her education at the Chiefs' Children's School (later known as the Royal School). She, along with her classmates, had been formally proclaimed by Kamehameha III as eligible for the throne of the Kingdom of Hawaii.{{cite news|title=CALENDAR: Princes and Chiefs eligible to be Rulers|newspaper=The Polynesian|location=Honolulu|date=July 20, 1844|volume=1|issue=9|at=p. 1, col. 3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1844-07-20/ed-1/seq-1|accessdate=October 5, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170311050237/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1844-07-20/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=March 11, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{harvnb|Cooke|Cooke|1937|pages=v–vi}}; {{harvnb|Van Dyke|2008|page=364}}; {{harvnb|Pratt|1920|pages=52–55}} Liliʻuokalani later noted that these "pupils were exclusively persons whose claims to the throne were acknowledged."{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|page=5}} She, along with her two older brothers James Kaliokalani and David Kalākaua, and her thirteen royal cousins, was taught in English by American missionaries [[Amos Starr Cooke]] and his wife, Juliette Montague Cooke.{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=5–9}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=45–46}} The children were taught reading, spelling, penmanship, arithmetic, geometry, algebra, physics, geography, history, bookkeeping, singing and English composition by the missionary couple who had to control the moral and sexual development of their charges.{{harvnb|Kanahele|1999|pages=23–39}}; {{harvnb|Kanahele|2002|pages=21–54}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=5–9}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=47–68}} Liliʻuokalani was placed in the youngest section of the class with Princess [[Victoria Kamāmalu]], [[Mary Polly Paaaina|Mary Polly Paʻaʻāina]], and [[John William Pitt Kinau|John William Pitt Kīnaʻu]].{{sfn|Kanahele|1999|pages=30–34}} In later life, Liliʻuokalani would look back unfavorably on her early education remembering being "sent hungry to bed" and the 1848 [[measles]] epidemic that claimed the life of a classmate [[Moses Kekūāiwa]] and her younger sister Kaʻiminaʻauao. The boarding school run by the Cookes was discontinued around 1850, so she, along with her former classmate Victoria, was sent to the relocated day school (also called Royal School) run by Reverend Edward G. Beckwith.{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|page=9}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|page=72}} On May 5, 1853, she finished third in her class with Victoria and [[Nancy Sumner]] in the final exams.{{sfn|Topolinski|1975|pages=32–34, 38}} In 1865, after her marriage, she informally attended Oʻahu College (modern day [[Punahou School]]) and received instruction under [[Susan Tolman Mills]], who later cofounded [[Mills College]] in California.{{sfn|Allen|1982|pages=109–110}} == Courtship and married life == [[File:Haleakala - the C. R. Bishop Residence, oil on canvas painting by D. Howard Hitchcock, 1899, Bishop Museum.JPG|thumb|[[Haleʻākala]], oil on canvas by [[D. Howard Hitchcock]], 1899]] After the boarding school was discontinued in 1850, Liliʻuokalani lived with her ''hānai'' parents at [[Haleʻākala]], which she referred to in later life as her childhood home. Around this time, her ''hānai'' sister Pauahi married the American [[Charles Reed Bishop]] against the wishes of their parents but reconciled with them shortly before Pākī's death in 1855. Kōnia died two years afterward and Liliʻuokalani came under the Bishops' guardianship. During this period, Liliʻuokalani became a part of the young social elite under the reign of [[Kamehameha IV]] who ascended to the throne in 1855.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=69–84}}; {{harvnb|King|Roth|2006|page=21}}; {{cite news|last=Taylor|first=Albert Pierce|title=Court Beauties of Fifty Years Ago|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=June 12, 1910|volume=VII|issue=388|page=13|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1910-06-12/ed-1/seq-13/|accessdate=September 26, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109054043/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1910-06-12/ed-1/seq-13/|archivedate=January 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In 1856, Kamehameha IV announced his intent to marry [[Queen Emma of Hawaii|Emma Rooke]], one of their classmates. However, according to Liliʻuokalani, certain elements of the court argued "there is no other chief equal to you in birth and rank but the adopted daughter of Paki,"{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|page=12}}{{#tag:ref|According to American Commissioner to Hawaii, [[David L. Gregg]], "Pakea [sic] was more unequivocal in his condemnation of the match. He expressed his opinion that his daughter Lydia Paki was more eligible, but declared that if neither the King nor any high chief thought proper to marry her, he would have her married to some good white man, which after all might be much more for her good."{{sfn|Gregg|1982|pages=316–317}}|group=note}} which infuriated the King and brought the Queen to tears. Despite this upset, Liliʻuokalani was regarded as a close friend of the new Queen, and she served as a maid of honor during the royal wedding alongside Princess Victoria Kamāmalu and [[Mary Pitman Ailau|Mary Pitman]].{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=81–84}}; {{harvnb|Kanahele|1999|pages=60–62}}; {{cite news|title=His Majesty's Marriage|newspaper=The Polynesian|location=Honolulu|date=June 21, 1856|volume=XIII|issue=7|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1856-06-21/ed-1/seq-2/|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202054733/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1856-06-21/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=February 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Marriage Of His Majesty Kamehameha IV|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=July 2, 1856|volume=1|issue=1|at=Image 2, col. 4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1856-07-02/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171001035922/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1856-07-02/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=October 1, 2017|df=mdy-all}} At official state occasions, she served as an attendant and [[lady-in-waiting]] in Queen Emma's retinue. Visiting British dignitaries [[Jane Franklin|Lady Franklin]] and her niece Sophia Cracroft noted in 1861 that the "Honble. Lydia Paki" was "the highest unmarried woman in the Kingdom".{{harvnb|Cracroft|Franklin|Queen Emma|1958|pages=111–112}} Marriage consideration had begun early on for her. American merchant [[Gorham D. Gilman]], a houseguest of the Pākīs, had courted her unsuccessfully when she was fifteen. Around the time of Kōnia's final illness in 1857, Liliʻuokalani was briefly engaged to [[Lunalilo|William Charles Lunalilo]]. They shared an interest in music composition and had known each other from childhood. He had been betrothed from birth to Princess Victoria, the king's sister, but disagreements with her brothers prevented the marriage from materializing. Thus, Lunalilo proposed to Liliʻuokalani during a trip to [[Lahaina]] to be with Kōnia. A short-lived dual engagement occurred in which Liliʻuokalani was matched to Lunalilo and her brother Kalakaua to Princess Victoria. She ultimately broke off the engagement because of the urging of King Kamehameha IV and the opposition of the Bishops to the union.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=77, 84–89}}; {{harvnb|Haley|2014|page=217}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=14–15}}{{#tag:ref|Historian Helena G. Allen noted that this "would undoubtedly been a disasterous [sic] marriage".{{sfn|Allen|1982|page=89}}|group=note}} Afterward, she became romantically involved with the American-born [[John Owen Dominis]], a staff member for Prince Lot Kapuāiwa (the future Kamehameha V) and secretary to King Kamehameha IV. Dominis was the son of Captain John Dominis, of [[Trieste]], and [[Mary Dominis|Mary Lambert Jones]], of [[Boston]]. According to Liliʻuokalani's memoir, they had known each other from childhood when he watched the royal children from a school next to the Cookes'. During a court excursion, Dominis escorted her home despite falling from his horse and breaking his leg.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=52, 84–89}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=11–13, 16}} [[File:John Owen Dominis (PP-71-2-023).jpg|thumb|[[John Owen Dominis]], who later became Governor of Oʻahu]] From 1860 to 1862, Liliʻuokalani and Dominis were engaged with the wedding set on her twenty-fourth birthday. This was postponed to September 16, 1862, out of respect for the death of Prince [[Albert Kamehameha]], son of Kamehameha IV and Queen Emma. The wedding was held at Haleʻākala, the residence of the Bishops. The ceremony was officiated by Reverend [[Samuel Chenery Damon]] in the [[Church of Hawaii|Anglican]] rites. Her bridemaids were her former classmates [[Elizabeth Kekaʻaniau]] and Martha Swinton. King Kamehameha IV and other members of the royal family were honored guests. The couple moved into the Dominises' residence, [[Washington Place]] in Honolulu. Through his wife and connections with the king, Dominis would later become Governor of [[Governors of Oahu|Oʻahu]] and [[Governors of Maui|Maui]].{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=84–89; 98–99, 103–104}}; {{harvnb|Kanahele|2002|page=97}}; {{cite news|title=Notes of the Week|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=September 18, 1862|volume=VII|issue=12|at=Image 2, col. 5|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1862-09-18/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108164620/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1862-09-18/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Marela|newspaper=Ka Nupepa Kuokoa|location=Honolulu|date=September 20, 1862|volume=I|issue=43|page=3|url=http://nupepa.org/gsdl2.5/cgi-bin/nupepa?e=d-0nupepa--00-0-0--010---4----text-mid--0-1l--1haw-Zz-1--en-20-about--20-00031-0000utfZz-8-00-0003-1-0000utfZz-8-00&cl=CL1.24.2&d=HASH018d243f3ca726f62f144380.3&gg=prev|accessdate=September 26, 2016}}; {{cite news|title=Na Mea Mare|newspaper=Ka Hoku o ka Pakipika|location=Honolulu|date=September 18, 1862|volume=II|issue=52|page=2|url=http://nupepa.org/gsdl2.5/cgi-bin/nupepa?e=d-0nupepa--00-0-0--010---4----text-prev--0-1l--1haw-Zz-1--en-20-about--20-00031-0000utfZz-8-00-0003-1-0000utfZz-8-00&a=d&cl=CL1.10.2&d=HASH019b9459d02f1e2f7f745385.2|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} The union was reportedly an unhappy one with much gossip about Dominis' infidelities and domestic strife between Liliʻuokalani and Dominis' mother Mary who disapproved of the marriage of her son with a Hawaiian.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=109–153, 159–161}}; {{harvnb|Haley|2014|page=200}}; {{harvnb|Blount|1895|page=996}} They never had any children of their own, but, against the wish of her husband, Liliʻuokalani adopted three ''hānai'' children: [[Lydia Kaʻonohiponiponiokalani Aholo]], the daughter of a [[Luther Aholo|family friend]]; [[Joseph Kaiponohea ʻAeʻa]], the son of a retainer; and [[John ʻAimoku Dominis]], her husband's son.{{sfn|Bonura|Witmer|2013|pages=109–115}}{{#tag:ref|John Dominis ʻAimoku formally changed his surname to Dominis in 1910.{{sfn|Allen|1982|pages=159–160}}|group=note}} After her marriage, she retained her position in the court circle of Kamehameha IV and later his brother and successor Kamehameha V. She assisted Queen Emma and King Kamehameha IV in raising funds to build [[The Queen's Medical Center|The Queen's Hospital]]. In 1864, she and Pauahi helped Princess Victoria established the [[Kaʻahumanu Society]], a female-led organization aimed at the relief of the elderly and the ill. At the request of Kamehameha V, she composed "[[He Mele Lāhui Hawaiʻi]]" in 1866 as the new Hawaiian national anthem. This was in use until replaced by her brother's composition "[[Hawaiʻi Ponoʻī]]". During the 1869 visit of [[Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha|Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh]] and the ''[[HMS Galatea (1859)|Galatea]]'', she entertained the British prince with a traditional Hawaiian [[luau]] at her [[Waikiki]] residence of Hamohamo.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=91–98–99, 116–117, 122–123}}; {{harvnb|Smith|1956|pages=8–10}} == Heir apparent and regency == === Elections of 1874 === {{Main|Honolulu Courthouse riot}} When Kamehameha V died in 1872 with no heir, the [[1864 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii]] called for the [[Legislature of the Kingdom of Hawaii|legislature]] to elect the next monarch. Following a non-binding referendum and subsequent unanimous vote in the legislature, [[Lunalilo]] became the first [[elected king]] of Hawaii.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1953|pages=239–245}}; {{cite news|title=Death of the King|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=December 14, 1872|volume=XVII|issue=24|at=Image 2, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1872-12-14/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119064701/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1872-12-14/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Meeting of the Assembly! Election of Prince Lunalilo As King! Immense Enthusiasm!|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=January 11, 1873|volume=XVII|issue=28|at=Image 4, col. 4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1873-01-11/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119064704/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1873-01-11/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=November 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=The Accession to the Throne|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=January 11, 1873|volume=XVII|issue=28|at=Image 3, Col. 4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1873-01-11/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119064703/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1873-01-11/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=November 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Lunalilo died without an heir in 1874. In the [[Hawaii monarchal election, 1874|election that followed]], Liliʻuokalani's brother, David Kalākaua, ran against Emma, the [[dowager queen]] of [[Kamehameha IV]].{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=3–16}} The choice of Kalākaua by the legislature, and the subsequent announcement, caused a [[Honolulu Courthouse riot|riot at the courthouse]]. US and British troops were landed, and some of Emma's supporters were arrested. The results of the election strained the relationship between Emma and the Kalākaua family.{{harvnb|Kanahele|1999|pages=315–319}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=40–41, 45–49}}{{#tag:ref|Historian [[George Kanahele]] noted that the rift was largely between Liliʻuokalani and Emma since her brother actively sought reconciliation with the dowager queen. During the coronation of Kalākaua, Queen Emma was given greater precedence over Liliʻuokalani and her husband, an action that infuriated Liliʻuokalani.{{sfn|Kanahele|1999|page=318, 353–354}}|group=note}} After his accession, Kalākaua gave royal titles and styles to his surviving siblings, his sisters, Princess Lydia Kamakaʻeha Dominis and Princess Miriam Likelike Cleghorn, as well as his brother William Pitt Leleiohoku, whom he named heir to the Hawaiian throne as Kalākaua and [[Queen Kapiolani|Queen Kapiʻolani]] had no children of their own.{{#tag:ref|Allen noted, "According to ''[[Thrum's Hawaiian Annual|Thrum's Annual]]'', two new princesses were designated: 'Princess Likelike and Princess Kamakaeha Dominis.' There is no evidence of an official act on the part of Kalakaua [at this time]."{{sfn|Allen|1982|page=138}} On February 10, 1883, Kalākaua officially created her a Princess of the Kingdom by Letters Patent along with other members of his family who been using their courtesy titles for the years between 1873 and 1883.{{cite news|title=By Authority|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=February 17, 1883|at=Image 5. col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1883-02-17/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108233807/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1883-02-17/ed-1/seq-5/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}}|group=note|name="Princess"}} Leleiohoku died without an heir in 1877.{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=53–55}} Leleiohoku's ''hānai'' (adoptive) mother, [[Keʻelikōlani|Ruth Keʻelikōlani]], wanted to be named heir, but the king's cabinet ministers objected as that would place Bernice Pauahi Bishop, Ruth's first cousin, next in line.{{sfn|Kanahele|1999|page=318}} This would put the Kamehamehas back in succession to the throne again, which Kalākaua did not wish. On top of that, Kalākaua's court genealogists had already cast doubt on Ruth's direct lineage, and in doing so placed doubt on Bernice's.{{sfn|Kanahele|2002|pages=151–152}} At noon on April 10, Liliʻuokalani became the newly designated heir apparent to the throne of Hawaii.{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=53–55}}; {{harvnb|Kanahele|2002|pages=151–152}}; {{cite news|title=The Heir Apparent|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=April 14, 1877|volume=XXI|issue=42|at=Image 2, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1877-04-14/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108233803/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015418/1877-04-14/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Proclamation of the Heir Apparent|newspaper=The Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|date=April 18, 1877|volume=XIII|issue=16|page=2|url=https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1877-04-18/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|10=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180727145536/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1877-04-18/ed-1/seq-2/|archive-date=July 27, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} It was at this time that Kalākaua had her name changed to ''Liliʻuokalani'' (the "[[wikt:smarting#Noun|smarting]] of the royal ones"), replacing her given name of Liliʻu and her baptismal name of Lydia.{{sfn|Allen|1982|page=147}} In 1878, Liliʻuokalani and Dominis sailed to California for her health. They stayed in San Francisco and Sacramento where she visited the [[Crocker Art Museum]].{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=61–68}}{{cite news|title=The Hawaiian Princess|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|location=San Francisco|date=April 13, 1878|volume=|issue=|page=2|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22727002/the_hawaiian_princess_san_francisco/|accessdate=August 11, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180812115532/https://www.newspapers.com/clip/22727002/the_hawaiian_princess_san_francisco/|archive-date=August 12, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} During [[Kalākaua's 1881 world tour]], Liliʻuokalani served as Regent in his absence.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|page=227}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|page=75–85}}; {{harvnb|Middleton|2015|page=530}} It was during this regency that Liliʻuokalani visited the leper settlement at [[Kalaupapa Leprosy Settlement and National Historical Park|Kalaupapa]] on [[Molokai|Molokaʻi]] in September.{{harvnb|Inglis|2013|pages=130}}; {{harvnb|Law|2012|page=125}} She was too overcome to speak and John Makini Kapena, one of her brother's ministers, had to address the people on her behalf. After the visit, in the name of her brother, Liliʻuokalani made [[Father Damien]] a knight commander of the [[Royal Order of Kalākaua]] for his service to her subjects. She also convinced the governmental board of health to set aside land for a leprosy hospital at [[Kakaako|Kakaʻako]].{{harvnb|Law|2012|page=125}} She made a second visit to the settlement with Queen Kapiolani in 1884.{{harvnb|Inglis|2013|pages=88–89}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1886|pages=iii–xvii}} === Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria === [[File:Liliuokalani in London (PPWD-16-4.014).jpg|thumb|right|Liliʻuokalani at [[Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria|Queen Victoria's Golden Jubilee]]]] {{Main|Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria|Bayonet Constitution}} In April 1887, Kalākaua sent a delegation to attend the [[Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria]] in London. It included his wife Queen Kapiʻolani, the Princess Liliʻuokalani and her husband, as well as Court Chamberlain Colonel [[Curtis P. Iaukea]] acting as the official envoy of the King.{{harvnb|Iaukea|2012|page=30}}; {{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=341}} The party landed in San Francisco and traveled across the United States visiting Washington, D.C., Boston and New York City, where they boarded a ship for the United Kingdom. While in the American capital, they were received by President [[Grover Cleveland]] and his wife.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=340–343}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|page=116–176}} In London, Kapiʻolani and Liliʻuokalani received an official audience with Queen Victoria at [[Buckingham Palace]]. Queen Victoria greeted both Hawaiian royals with affection, and recalled Kalākaua's visit in 1881. They attended the special Jubilee service at [[Westminster Abbey]] and were seated with other foreign royal guests, and with members of the Royal Household.{{harvnb|Iaukea|2012|pages=30–31}} Shortly after the Jubilee celebrations, they learned of the [[Bayonet Constitution]] that Kalākaua had been forced to sign under the threat of death. They canceled their tour of Europe and returned to Hawaii.{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|page=171–176}}; {{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=340–343}} Liliʻuokalani was approached on December 20 and 23 by James I. Dowsett, Jr. and [[William Richards Castle|William R. Castle]], members of the legislature's [[Reform Party (Hawaii)|Reform (Missionary) Party]], proposing her ascension to the throne if her brother Kalākaua were removed from power. Historian Ralph S. Kuykendall stated that she gave a conditional "if necessary" response; however, Liliʻuokalani's account was that she firmly turned down both men.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|page=415}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|page=186–188}} In 1889, a part ''kānaka maoli'' ([[Native Hawaiian]]) officer [[Robert William Wilcox|Robert W Wilcox]], who resided in Liliʻuokalani's Palama residence, instigated an unsuccessful [[Wilcox rebellion of 1889|rebellion]] to overthrow the Bayonet Constitution.{{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|page=191–201}}; {{harvnb|Siler|2012|page=176}}; {{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=424–432}} === Death of Kalākaua === {{Main|Death and two state funerals of Kalākaua}} Kalākaua arrived in California aboard the [[USS Charleston (C-2)|USS ''Charleston'']] on November 25, 1890. There was uncertainty as to the purpose of the king's trip. Minister of Foreign Affairs [[John Adams Cummins]] reported that the trip was solely for the king's health and would not extend beyond California, while local newspapers and the British commissioner James Hay Wodehouse speculated that the king might go further east to Washington, D.C. to negotiate a treaty to extend the existing exclusive US access rights to Pearl Harbor, or the annexation of the kingdom. The [[McKinley Tariff]] Act had crippled the Hawaiian sugar industry by removing the duties on sugar imports from other countries into the US, eliminating the previous Hawaiian duty-free advantage under the [[Reciprocity Treaty of 1875]].{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=466 –469}}{{sfn|Spickard|Rondilla|Wright|2002|page=316}} After failing to persuade the king to stay, Liliʻuokalani wrote that he and Hawaiian ambassador to the United States [[Henry A. P. Carter]] planned to discuss the tariff situation in Washington.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=470–474}}; {{harvnb|Krout|1898|page=10}}; {{harvnb|Thrum|1892|page=126}}; {{harvnb|Dando-Collins|2014|page=42}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=225–226}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=206–207}} In his absence, Liliʻuokalani was left in charge as regent for the second time. In her memoir, she wrote that "Nothing worthy of record transpired during the closing days of 1890, and the opening weeks of 1891."{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|page=470}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=225–229}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=206–209}} Upon arriving in California, Kalākaua, whose health had been declining, stayed in a suite at the [[Palace Hotel, San Francisco|Palace Hotel]] in San Francisco.{{sfn|Dando-Collins|2014|page=42}}{{cite news|last=Rego|first=Nilda|title=Days Gone By: 1890: Hawaii’s King Kalakaua visits San Francisco|date=April 25, 2013|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2013/04/25/days-gone-by-1890-hawaiis-king-kalakaua-visits-san-francisco/|location=San Francisco|newspaper=The Mercury News|accessdate=November 3, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104075353/http://www.mercurynews.com/2013/04/25/days-gone-by-1890-hawaiis-king-kalakaua-visits-san-francisco/|archivedate=November 4, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Traveling throughout Southern California and Northern Mexico, the monarch suffered a stroke in [[Santa Barbara, California|Santa Barbara]]{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|page=472}} and was rushed back to San Francisco. Kalākaua fell into a coma in his suite on January 18, and died two days later on January 20.{{sfn|Dando-Collins|2014|page=42}}{{sfn|Vowell|2011|page=91}} The official cause of death was "[[Bright's disease|Bright's Disease]] with Uremic [[Sepsis|Blood Poisoning]]."{{sfn|Mcdermott|Choy| Guerrero|2015|page=59}} The news of Kalākaua's death did not reach Hawaii until January 29 when the ''Charleston'' returned to Honolulu with the remains of the king.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=473–474}} == Reign == On January 29, 1891, in the presence of the cabinet ministers and the supreme court justices, Liliʻuokalani took the oath of office to uphold the constitution, and became the first and only queen of the Kingdom of Hawaii.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=474–476}}{{cite news|title=By Authority|newspaper=The Daily Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=January 30, 1891|volume=XV|issue=25|at=Image 2, col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1891-01-30/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003030701/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1891-01-30/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=October 3, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The first few weeks of her reign were obscured by the funeral of her brother. After the end of the period of mourning, one of her first acts was to request the formal resignation of the holdover cabinet from her brother's reign. These ministers refused, and asked for a ruling by the Hawaii Supreme Court. All the justices but one ruled in favor of the Queen's decision, and the ministers resigned. Liliʻuokalani appointed [[Samuel Parker (Hawaii)|Samuel Parker]], [[Hermann A. Widemann]], and [[William A. Whiting]], and reappointed Charles N. Spencer (from the hold-over cabinet), as her new cabinet ministers. On March 9, with the approval of the House of Nobles, as required by the Hawaiian constitution, she named as successor her niece [[Kaʻiulani]], the only daughter of [[Archibald Scott Cleghorn]] and her sister Princess Likelike, who had died in 1887.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=476–478}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=245}}; {{cite news|title=The Succession Princess Kaiulani Proclaimed Successor to the Hawaiian Throne|newspaper=The Daily Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=March 9, 1891|volume=XV|issue=57|at=Image 2, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1891-03-09/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171003030844/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1891-03-09/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=October 3, 2017|df=mdy-all}} From April to July, Liliʻuokalani paid the customary visits to the main Hawaiian Islands, including a revisit to the leper settlement of [[Kalaupapa Leprosy Settlement and National Historical Park|Kalaupapa]]. Historian [[Ralph Simpson Kuykendall]] noted, "Everywhere she was accorded the homage traditionally paid by the Hawaiian people to their ''alii''."{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|page=484}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=246–253}}; {{harvnb|Inglis|2013|page=136}} [[File:Liliuokalani at Waipio, Oahu in 1891.jpg|thumb|300px|Liliʻuokalani at [[Waipio, Hawaii|Waipiʻo]] during her royal circuit of Oʻahu, 1891]] Following her accession, John Owen Dominis was given the title [[Prince Consort]] and restored to the Governorship of Oʻahu, which had been abolished following the Bayonet Constitution of 1887.{{harvnb|Newbury|2001|pages=16, 29–30}}; {{cite news|title=By Authority|newspaper=The Daily Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=March 2, 1891|volume=XV|issue=51|at=Image 2, col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1891-03-02/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108164645/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1891-03-02/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Dominis' death on August 27, seven months into her reign, greatly affected the new Queen. Liliʻuokalani later wrote: "His death occurred at a time when his long experience in public life, his amiable qualities, and his universal popularity, would have made him an adviser to me for whom no substitute could possibly be found. I have often said that it pleased the Almighty Ruler of nations to take him away from me at precisely the time when I felt that I most needed his counsel and companionship."{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=255–258}}; {{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=486–486}}; {{harvnb|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=29, 220–225}} Cleghorn, her sister's widower, was appointed to succeed Dominis as Governor of Oʻahu. In 1892, Liliʻuokalani would also restore the positions of governor for the other three main islands for her friends and supporters.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=485–486}}; {{harvnb|Newbury|2001|pages=16, 29–30}} From May 1892 to January 1893, the legislature of the Kingdom convened for an unprecedented 171 days, which later historians such as Albertine Loomis and Helena G. Allen dubbed the "[[1892 Legislative Session of the Kingdom of Hawaii|Longest Legislature]]".{{harvnb|Loomis|1963|pages=7–27}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pages=269–270}} This session was dominated by political infighting between and within the four parties: [[National Reform Party (Hawaii)|National Reform]], [[Reform Party (Hawaii)|Reform]], [[National Liberal Party (Hawaii)|National Liberal]] and Independent; none were able to gain a majority. Debates heard on the floor of the houses concerned the popular demand for a new constitution and the passage of a [[lottery]] bill and an [[opium]] licensing bill, aimed at alleviating the economic crisis caused by the McKinley Tariff. The main issues of contention between the new monarch and the legislators were the retention of her cabinet ministers, since political division prevented Liliʻuokalani from appointing a balanced council and the 1887 constitution gave the legislature the power to vote for the dismissal of her cabinet. Seven resolutions of want of confidence were introduced during this session, and four of her self-appointed cabinets (the Widemann, [[Edward C. Macfarlane|Macfarlane]], [[William H. Cornwell|Cornwell]], and [[George Norton Wilcox|Wilcox]] cabinets) were ousted by votes of the legislature. On January 13, 1893, after the legislature dismissed the George Norton Wilcox cabinet (which had political sympathies to the Reform Party), Liliʻuokalani appointed the new Parker cabinet consisting of Samuel Parker, as minister of foreign affairs; [[John F. Colburn]], as minister of the interior; William H. Cornwell, as minister of finance; and [[Arthur P. Peterson]], as attorney general.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=562–563, 573–581}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|page=174–175}}; {{harvnb|Moblo|1998|pages=229–232}}; {{cite news|title=A New Cabinet – Some New Ministers for the Public to Swallow|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=January 14, 1893|volume=XVII|issue=3277|page=4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1893-01-14/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=November 12, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170109053928/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1893-01-14/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=January 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}} She had chosen these men specifically to support her plan of promulgating a new constitution while the legislature was not in session.{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=581–583}} === Promulgating a new constitution === {{Main|Proposed 1893 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii}} The precipitating event{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|page=582}} leading to the 1893 overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii was the attempt by Queen Liliʻuokalani to promulgate a new constitution to regain powers for the monarchy and Native Hawaiians that had been lost under the Bayonet Constitution. Her opponents, who were led by two Hawaiian citizens [[Lorrin A. Thurston]] and W. O. Smith and included six Hawaiian citizens, five U.S. citizens and one German citizen,{{sfn|Blount|1895|page=588}}. Outraged by her attempt to promulgate a new constitution, they moved to depose the Queen, overthrow the monarchy, and seek Hawaii's annexation to the United States.{{#tag:ref|"W.D. Alexander (''History of Later Years of the Hawaiian Monarchy and the Revolution of 1893'', {{harvnb|Alexander|1896|page=37}}) gives the following as the wording of Thurston's motion [to launch the coup]: 'That preliminary steps be taken at once to form and declare a Provisional Government with a view to annexation to the United States.' Thurston later wrote that his motion was 'substantially as follows: "I move that it is the sense of this meeting that the solution of the present situation is annexation to the United States."'(''Memoirs'', p. 250) Lt. Lucien Young (''The Boston at Hawaii'', p. 175) gives the following version of the motion: 'Resolved, That it is the sense of this committee that in view of the present unsatisfactory state of affairs, the proper course to pursue is to abolish the monarchy and apply for annexation to the United States.'"{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=587–588}}|group=note}}{{sfn|Russ|1959|page=90}} Shortly after her accession, Liliʻuokalani began to receive petitions to re-write the Bayonet Constitution{{#tag:ref|The [[Bayonet Constitution]] was named because it had been signed by the previous monarch under threat of violence from a militia composed of armed American and Europeans calling themselves the "[[Honolulu Rifles]]".{{sfn|Lee|1993|pages=4–5}}|group=note}} through the two major political parties of the time, Hui Kālaiʻāina and the National Reform Party.{{#tag:ref|"She ... defended her act[ions] by showing that, out of a possible 9,500 native voters in 1892, 6,500 asked for a new Constitution."{{sfn|Russ|1959|page=67}}|group=note}} Supported by two-thirds of the registered voters,{{sfn|Lobo|Talbot|Carlston|2016|page=122}} she moved to abrogate the existing 1887 constitution, but her cabinet withheld their support, knowing what her opponents' likely response would be.{{#tag:ref|The Queen's new cabinet "had been in office less than a week, and whatever they thought about the need for a new constitution ... they knew enough about the temper of the queen's opponents to realize that they would endure the chance to challenge her, and no minister of the crown could look forward ... to that confrontation".{{sfn|Daws|1968|page=271}}|group=note}} The [[Proposed 1893 Constitution of the Kingdom of Hawaii|proposed constitution]] (co-written by the Queen and two legislators, [[Joseph Nāwahī]] and [[William Pūnohu White]]) would have restored the power to the monarchy, and voting rights to economically disenfranchised native Hawaiians and Asians.{{sfn|Daws|1968|page=271}}{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=582–586}} Her ministers and closest friends were all opposed to this plan; they tried unsuccessfully to dissuade her from pursuing these initiatives, both of which came to be used against her in the brewing constitutional crisis.{{sfn|Blount|1895|page=496}} === Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii === {{Main|Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii}} [[File:USS Boston landing force, 1893 (PP-36-3-002).jpg|300px|thumb|The [[USS Boston (1884)|USS ''Boston'']]'s landing force on duty at the Arlington Hotel, Honolulu]] The political fallout led to citywide political rallies and meetings in Honolulu. Anti-monarchists, annexationists, and leading Reform Party politicians that included [[Lorrin A. Thurston]], a grandson of American missionaries, and Kalākaua's former cabinet ministers under the Bayonet Constitution, formed the [[Committee of Safety (Hawaii)|Committee of Safety]] in protest of the "revolutionary" action of the queen and conspired to depose her. Thurston and the Committee of Safety derived their support primarily from the American and European business class residing in Hawaiʻi. Most of the leaders of the overthrow were American and European citizens who were also Kingdom subjects. They also included legislators, government officers, and a justice of the Hawaiian Supreme Court.{{sfn|Twigg-Smith|1998|pages=135–166}}{{sfn|Andrade|1996|page=130}} In response, [[royalists]] and loyalists formed the Committee of Law and Order and met at the palace square on January{{nbsp}}16, 1893. Nāwahī, White, Robert W. Wilcox, and other pro-monarchist leaders gave speeches in support for the queen and the government. To try to appease the instigators, the queen and her supporters abandoned attempts to unilaterally promulgate a constitution .{{cite news|title=Popular Meeting – Over Two Thousand Person Assemble on Palace Square – They Pass a Resolution Upholding the Queen and the Government|newspaper=The Daily Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=January 17, 1893|volume=|issue=|page=2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1893-01-17/ed-1/seq-2/|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119064916/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1893-01-17/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{harvnb|Kuykendall|1967|pages=586–594}}; {{harvnb|Alexander|1896|pages=37–51}} The same day, the Marshal of the Kingdom, [[Charles Burnett Wilson]], was tipped off by detectives to the imminent planned coup. Wilson requested [[Warrant (law)|warrants]] to arrest the 13-member council of the Committee of Safety, and put the Kingdom under [[martial law]]. Because the members had strong political ties to [[United States Minister to Hawaii]] [[John L. Stevens]], the requests were repeatedly denied by the queen's cabinet, who feared that the arrests would escalate the situation.
