After a failed negotiation with Thurston,{{sfn|Twombly|1900|page=333}} Wilson began to collect his men for the confrontation. Wilson and captain of the [[Royal Guards of Hawaii|Royal Household Guard]] [[Samuel Nowlein]] had rallied a force of 496 men who were kept at hand to protect the queen.{{sfn|Young|1899|page=252}} [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]] from the [[USS Boston (1884)|USS ''Boston'']] and two companies of US sailors landed and took up positions at the US Legation, the Consulate, and Arion Hall. The sailors and Marines did not enter the palace grounds or take over any buildings, and never fired a shot, but their presence served effectively in intimidating royalist defenders. Historian William Russ states, "the injunction to prevent fighting of any kind made it impossible for the monarchy to protect itself".{{harvnb|Russ|1959|page=350}} The queen was deposed on January 17, and the [[Provisional Government of Hawaii|provisional government]] established under pro-annexation leader [[Sanford B. Dole]] was officially recognized by Stevens as the ''[[de facto]]'' government.{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=387–388}}{{sfn|Allen|1982|page=294}}{{sfn|Alexander|1896|page=65}} She temporarily relinquished her throne to the United States, rather than the Dole-led government, in hopes that the United States would restore Hawaii's sovereignty to the rightful holder.{{sfn|Tabrah|1984|page=102}} The government under Dole began using ʻIolani Palace as its executive building.{{sfn|Alexander|1896|page=66}}{{sfn|Siler|2012|page=250}} A delegation departed for Washington D.C. on January 19, to ask for immediate annexation by the United States.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=605–610}} At the request of the provisional government, Stevens proclaimed Hawaii a protectorate of the United States on February 1, to temporarily provide a buffer against domestic upheaval and interference by foreign governments.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=599–605}}{{sfn|Alexander|1896|pages=66–67}} The US flag was raised over the palace, and [[martial law]] was enforced. The annexation treaty presented to the US Senate contained a provision to grant Liliʻuokalani a $20,000 per annum lifetime pension, and Kaʻiulani a lump-sum payment of $150,000. The queen protested the proposed annexation in a January 19 letter to President [[Benjamin Harrison]]. She sent Prince [[David Kawānanakoa]] and [[Paul Neumann (Attorney General)|Paul Neumann]] to represent her.{{sfn|Alexander|1896|pages=71–76}} Neumann delivered a letter from the queen to Grover Cleveland, who began his second non-consecutive term as president on March 4.{{sfn|Alexander|1896|page=74}} The Cleveland administration commissioned the [[Blount Report]], and based on its findings, concluded that the overthrow of Liliʻuokalani was illegal, and that Stevens and American military troops had acted inappropriately in support of those who carried out the overthrow. On November 16, Cleveland sent his minister [[Albert S. Willis]] to propose a return of the throne to Liliʻuokalani if she granted amnesty to everyone responsible. Her first response was that Hawaiian law called for property confiscation and the death penalty for treason, and that only her cabinet ministers could put aside the law in favor of amnesty.{{sfn|Calhoun|1988|page=150}}{{sfn|Love|2005|page=112}}{{sfn|Cleaver|2014|page=29}}{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|page=642}} Liliuokalani's extreme position lost her the goodwill of the Cleveland administration.{{cite book|author=Warren Zimmermann|title=First Great Triumph: How Five Americans Made Their Country a World Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_TPg3gNPWqQC&pg=PA290|year=2004|publisher=Farrar, Straus and Giroux|page=290}} Cleveland sent the issue to the Congress, stating, "The Provisional Government has not assumed a republican, or other constitutional form, but has remained a mere executive council, or oligarchy, without the consent of the people".{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Hawaiian Situation: The President's Message to Congress|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016187/1893-12-21/ed-1/seq-8/|accessdate=October 19, 2017|work=The National Tribune|location=Washington D.C.|date=December 21, 1893|at=p. 8, col. 4|via=[[Chronicling America]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109084436/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016187/1893-12-21/ed-1/seq-8/|archivedate=November 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The queen changed her position on the issue of amnesty, and on December 18, Willis demanded the provisional government reinstate her to the throne, but was refused. Congress responded with a US Senate investigation that resulted in the [[Morgan Report]] on February 26, 1894. It found Stevens and all parties except the queen "not guilty", absolving them of responsibility for the overthrow.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=642–645}} The provisional government formed the [[Republic of Hawaii]] on July 4 with Dole as its president, maintaining oligarchical control and a limited system of suffrage.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|pages=649–650}} == Arrest and imprisonment == [[File:Liliuokalani entering palace for trial of 1895 (PP-98-12-010).jpg|thumb|300px|Liliʻuokalani being escorted up the steps of the palace, where she was imprisoned after the counter-revolution of 1895]] At the beginning of January 1895, Robert W. Wilcox and Samuel Nowlein launched a [[1895 Counter-revolution in Hawaii|rebellion]] against the forces of the Republic with the aim of restoring the queen and the monarchy. Its ultimate failure led to the arrest of many of the participants and other sympathizers of the monarchy. Liliʻuokalani was also arrested and imprisoned in an upstairs bedroom at the palace on January 16, several days after the failed rebellion, when [[firearm]]s were found at her home of Washington Place after a tip from a prisoner.{{cite news|title=Queen Arrested|newspaper=The Daily Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=January 16, 1895|volume=IX|issue=1238|at=Image 3. col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1895-01-16/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171002221224/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1895-01-16/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=October 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=She Plotted|newspaper=The Hawaiian Star|location=Honolulu|date=January 17, 1895|volume=III|issue=557|at=p. 3, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1895-01-17/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171002221228/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1895-01-17/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=October 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}} During her imprisonment, she abdicated her throne in return for the release (and commutation of the death sentences) of her jailed supporters; six had been sentenced to be hanged including Wilcox and Nowlein.{{sfn|Siler|2012|pages=269–270}} She signed the document of abdication on January 24. In 1898, Liliʻuokalani wrote: {{quote|For myself, I would have chosen death rather than to have signed it; but it was represented to me that by my signing this paper all the persons who had been arrested, all my people now in trouble by reason of their love and loyalty towards me, would be immediately released. Think of my position, — sick, a lone woman in prison, scarcely knowing who was my friend, or who listened to my words only to betray me, without legal advice or friendly counsel, and the stream of blood ready to flow unless it was stayed by my pen.|Queen Liliʻuokalani|''Hawaii's Story By Hawaii's Queen''{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|page=274}}}} She was tried by the military commission of the Republic led by her former attorney general Whiting in the palace throne room on February 8. Defended at trial by another one of her former attorneys general [[Paul Neumann (Attorney General)|Paul Neumann]], she claimed ignorance but was sentenced to five years of hard labor in prison by the military tribunal and fined $5,000.{{sfn|Proto|2009|pages=93–112}}{{sfn|Siler|2012|page=268}}{{sfn|Borch|2014|pages=1–3}} The sentence was commuted on September 4, to imprisonment in the palace, attended by her lady-in-waiting [[Eveline Townsend Wilson]] (aka Kitty), wife of Marshal Wilson.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pp=123, 147, 187, 344–345, 347}}; {{cite news|title=Declines to Confess|newspaper=The Daily Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=February 6, 1895|volume=IX|issue=1256|at=p. 5, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1895-02-06/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170228124838/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1895-02-06/ed-1/seq-5/|archivedate=February 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Five Years in Parlor|newspaper=The Daily Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=February 27, 1895|volume=IX|issue=1274|at=p. 5, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1895-02-27/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170228124323/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1895-02-27/ed-1/seq-5/|archivedate=February 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In confinement she composed songs including "The Queen's Prayer" (''Ke Aloha o Ka Haku'' – "The Grace of the Lord").{{sfn|Siler|2012|page=274}} On October 13, 1896, the Republic of Hawaii gave her a full pardon and restored her civil rights.{{sfn|Siler|2012|pages=276–279}} "Upon receiving my full release, I felt greatly inclined to go abroad," Liliʻuokalani wrote in her memoir.{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|page=305}} From December 1896 through January 1897, she stayed in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]], with her husband's cousins William Lee and Sara White Lee, of the [[Lee & Shepard]] publishing house. During this period her long-time friend [[Julius A. Palmer Jr.]] became her secretary and stenographer, helping to write every letter, note, or publication. He was her literary support in the 1897 publication of the [[Kumulipo]] translation, and helped her in compiling a book of her songs. He assisted her as she wrote her memoir ''[[Hawaii's Story by Hawaii's Queen]]''.{{cite news|title=Julius A. Palmer's Story|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1897-09-29/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=September 25, 2017|work=The Independent (reprinted from [[The Boston Globe]])|date=September 29, 1897|at=Image 1, cols. 1–2; Image 4, cols. 3–5|via=[[Chronicling America]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108162842/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1897-09-29/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Sara Lee edited the book published in 1898 by Lee & Shepard.{{sfn|Allen|1982|page=356–359}} == Annexation == [[File:Liliuokalani, photograph by Prince, of Washington (cropped).jpg|thumb|Liliʻuokalani in Washington, c. 1898]] At the end of her visit in Massachusetts, Liliʻuokalani began to divide her time between Hawaii and Washington, D.C., where she worked to seek [[indemnity]] from the United States.{{cite news|title=A PACIFIC CABLE: Liliuokalani is in Boston|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=January 15, 1897|volume=XXV|issue=4507|at=Image 1, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1897-01-15/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171125080921/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1897-01-15/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=November 25, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=PRIVATE AFFAIRS: Liliuokalani and Capt. Palmer to Work McKinley|newspaper=Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|date=March 5, 1897|volume=XXXII|issue=19|at=Image 1, col. 6|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1897-03-05/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119071026/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1897-03-05/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=November 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}} She attended the [[First inauguration of William McKinley|inauguration]] of US President [[William McKinley]] on March 4, 1897, with a Republic of Hawaii passport personally issued to "Liliuokalani of Hawaii" by the republic's president Sanford B. Dole.{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|page=305}} On June 16, McKinley presented the United States Senate with a new version of the annexation treaty, one that eliminated the monetary compensation for Liliʻuokalani and Kaʻiulani.{{cite news|title=Treaty to Annex Hawaii|newspaper=[[Washington Times-Herald|The Times]]|location=Washington, D.C.|date=June 17, 1897|volume=|issue=1185|at=Image 1, col. 3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85054468/1897-06-17/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108125923/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85054468/1897-06-17/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Treaty to Annex Hawaii|newspaper=[[Washington Times-Herald|The Times]]|location=Washington, D.C.|date=June 17, 1897|volume=|issue=1185|at=Image 2, col. 4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85054468/1897-06-17/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108125916/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85054468/1897-06-17/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Liliʻuokalani filed an official protest with Secretary of State [[John Sherman]] the next day. The protest was witnessed by her agent and private secretary [[Joseph Heleluhe]], Wekeki Heleluhe, and Captain Julius A. Palmer Jr., reported to be her American secretary.{{cite news|title=By the Ex-Queen: Protest Made to the Annexation of Hawaii. An Appeal for Restoration. Authority of Present Government Denied. Document Signed in Washington and 'Julius' Witnessed the Signature|newspaper=Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|date=July 9, 1897|volume=XXXII|issue=55|at=Image 1, Col. 6|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1897-07-09/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108125909/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1897-07-09/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=The Ex-Queen's Protest|newspaper=The Times|location=Washington, D.C.|date=June 18, 1897|volume=|issue=1186|at=Image 1, col. 7|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85054468/1897-06-18/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108125911/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85054468/1897-06-18/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In June 1897 President McKinley signed the "Treaty for the Annexation for the Hawaiian Islands", but it failed to pass in the [[United States Senate]] after the [[Kūʻē Petitions]] were submitted by a commission of Native Hawaiian delegates consisting of [[James Keauiluna Kaulia]], [[David Kalauokalani]], [[William Auld (Hawaii)|William Auld]], and [[John Richardson (Hawaii)|John Richardson]]. Members of Hui Aloha ʻĀina collected over 21,000 signatures opposing an annexation treaty. Another 17,000 signatures were collected by members of Hui Kālaiʻāina but not submitted to the Senate because those signatures were also asking for restoration of the Queen. The petitions collectively were presented as evidence of the strong grassroots opposition of the Hawaiian community to annexation, and the treaty was defeated in the Senate— however, following its failure, Hawaii was annexed anyway via the [[Newlands Resolution]], a [[joint resolution]] of Congress, in July 1898, shortly after the outbreak of the Spanish–American War.{{sfn|Haley|2014|pages=317–336}}{{harvnb|Silva|2004|pages=123–163}}; {{cite web|last=Silva |first=Noenoe K. |title=The 1897 Petitions Protesting Annexation |work=The Annexation Of Hawaii: A Collection Of Document |year=1998 |publisher=University of Hawaii at Manoa |url=http://libweb.hawaii.edu/digicoll/annexation/petition/pet-intro.php |accessdate=December 19, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230013831/http://libweb.hawaii.edu/digicoll/annexation/petition/pet-intro.php |archivedate=December 30, 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{sfn|Parker|2007|page=205}}{{sfn|Mehmed|1998|pages=142–143}} The annexation ceremony was held on August 12, 1898, at ʻIolani Palace, now being used as the executive building of the government. President Sanford B. Dole handed over "the sovereignty and public property of the Hawaiian Islands" to United States Minister [[Harold M. Sewall]]. The flag of the Republic of Hawaii was lowered and the flag of the United States was raised in its place.{{sfn|Haley|2014|pages=336}} Liliʻuokalani and her family members and retainers boycotted the event and shuttered themselves away at Washington Place. Many Native Hawaiians and royalists followed suit and refused to attend the ceremony.{{sfn|Allen|1982|page=365}}{{sfn|Mehmed|1998|pages=141–144}} == Crown Lands of Hawaii == Prior to the 1848 division of land known as the [[Great Māhele]], during the reign of Kamehameha III, all land in Hawaii was owned by the monarchy. The Great Māhele subdivided the land among the monarchy, the government, and private ownership by tenants living on the land. What was reserved for the monarchy became known as the Crown Lands of Hawaii.{{sfn|Linnekin|1983|page=173}} When Hawaii was annexed, the Crown Lands were seized by the United States government. The Queen gave George Macfarlane her power of attorney in 1898 as part of her legal defense team in seeking indemnity for the government's seizure of the Crown Lands. She filed a protest with the United States Senate on December 20, 1898, requesting their return and claiming the lands were seized without due process or recompense.{{cite news|title=HAWAII'S EX-QUEEN: Protests Against the Seizure of Her Property|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Herald-Express|The Herald]]|location=Los Angeles|date=December 21, 1898|volume=26|issue=82|at=Image 1. col. 3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042461/1898-12-21/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170228124422/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042461/1898-12-21/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=February 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} {{Quote box | quote = That, the portion of the public domain heretofore known as Crown land is hereby declared to have been, on the twelfth day of August, eighteen hundred and ninety-eight, and prior thereto, the property of the Hawaiian government, and to be free and clear from any trust of or concerning the same, and from all claim of any nature what soever, upon the rents, issues, and profits thereof. It shall be subject to alienation and other uses as may be provided by law. | source = — Hawaiian Organic Act, Sec. 99{{harvnb|Thorpe|1909|p=903}} | align = right | width = 25% }} On April 30, 1900, the US Congress passed the [[Hawaiian Organic Act|Hawaii Organic Act]] establishing a government for the [[Territory of Hawaii]].{{sfn|Parker|2007|page=205}} The territorial government took control of the Crown Lands,{{sfn|Parker|2007|page=205}} which became the source of the "[[Ceded Lands]]" issue in Hawaii.{{sfn|Parker|2007|pages=205–207}} The ''[[San Francisco Call]]'' reported on May 31 that Macfarlane had informed them the Queen had exhausted her patience with Congress and intended to file a lawsuit against the government.{{harvnb|Proto|2009|p=132}}; {{cite news|title=Hawaiian Queen Decides to Sue for Crown Lands|newspaper=The [[San Francisco Call]]|location=San Francisco|date=May 31, 1900|volume=LXXXVII|issue=192|at=Image 12, col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1900-05-31/ed-1/seq-12/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171008030536/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85066387/1900-05-31/ed-1/seq-12/|archivedate=October 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Former [[United States Minister to Hawaii]] [[Edward M. McCook]] said he believed that once President McKinley began his second term on March 1, 1901, that the government would negotiate a generous settlement with Liliʻuokalani.{{cite news|title=Claims of Ex-Queen|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=July 5, 1903|volume=XXXII|issue=5589|at=p. 10, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1900-07-05/ed-1/seq-10/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108233809/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1900-07-05/ed-1/seq-10/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} During a 1900 Congressional deadlock, she departed for Honolulu with her Washington, D.C., Doctor Charles H. English (sometimes referred to as John H. English). Newspapers speculated that the Queen, having been diagnosed with cancer, was going home to die.{{cite news|title=Ex-Queen Liliuokalani Is Here on Her Way to Hawaii|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|location=San Francisco|date=May 20, 1900|volume=LXXI|issue=125|at=p. 1, col. 1|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/27582778/?terms=Joseph%2BHeleluhe|accessdate=October 15, 2017|via=Newspapers.com|subscription=yes|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108174627/https://www.newspapers.com/image/27582778/?terms=Joseph%2BHeleluhe|archivedate=January 8, 2018|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Ex-Queen Here Soon|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=May 31, 1900|volume=XXXI|issue=5559|at=p. 5, col. 3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1900-05-31/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109075420/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1900-05-31/ed-1/seq-5/|archivedate=November 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Historian Helena G. Allen made the case that English intended to gain title to crown lands for himself. According to Allen, the Queen balked at his draft of a settlement letter to Senator [[George Frisbie Hoar]] that he wanted her to copy in her handwriting and sign.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|pp=330–361, 368–369}} The Doctor was terminated "without cause" a month after her return and sued her.{{cite news|title=Court Notes|newspaper=The Independent|location=Honolulu|date=August 16, 1900|volume=XI|issue=1586|page=4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1900-08-16/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=October 2, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008054112/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1900-08-16/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=October 8, 2016|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Dr. English's Suit Against Liliuokalani|newspaper=The Honolulu Republican|location=Honolulu|date=September 5, 1900|volume=I|issue=71|at=Image 8, col. 3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047165/1900-09-05/ed-1/seq-8/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109075417/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047165/1900-09-05/ed-1/seq-8/|archivedate=November 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The ''Pacific Commercial Advertiser'' lamented in 1903, "There is something pathetic in the appearance of Queen Liliuokalani as a waiting claimant before Congress." It detailed her years-long residencies in the nation's capital seeking indemnity, while legislators offered empty promises, but nothing of substance.{{cite news|title=Liliuokalani's Claim|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=February 10, 1903|volume=XXXVII|issue=6399|at=Image 4, col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-02-10/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171125081302/https://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1903-02-10/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=November 25, 2017|df=mdy-all}} === ''Liliʻuokalani v. the United States'' === In 1909, Liliʻuokalani brought an unsuccessful lawsuit against the United States under the Fifth Amendment seeking the return of the Hawaiian Crown Lands.{{sfn|Parker|2007|page=205}} The US courts invoked an 1864 Kingdom Supreme Court decision over a case involving the Dowager Queen Emma and Kamehameha V, using it against her. In this decision the courts found that the Crown Lands were not necessarily the private possession of the monarch in the strictest sense of the term.{{sfn|Banner|2009|page=161}} == Later life and death == [[File:Liliuokalani in 1917.jpg|thumb|300px|Liliʻuokalani seated on the lanai of Washington Place in 1917]] Although Liliʻuokalani was never successful in more than a decade of legal pursuits for recompense from the United States government for seized land, in 1911 she was finally granted a lifetime pension of $1,250 a month by the Territory of Hawaii. Historian Sydney Lehua Iaukea noted that the grant never addressed the question of the legality of the seizure itself, and the figure was greatly reduced from what she had requested for recompense.{{harvnb|Iaukea|2012|pp=86, 181}}; {{cite news|title=Queen's Pension is Approved|newspaper=Evening Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=March 30, 1911|at=p. 2, col. 3|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016413/1911-03-30/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119064942/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016413/1911-03-30/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In April 1917, Liliʻuokalani raised the American flag at Washington Place in honor of five Hawaiian sailors who had perished in the sinking of the SS ''Aztec'' by [[Imperial Germany|German]] [[U-boat]]s. Her act was interpreted by many as her symbolic support of the United States.{{cite news|editor-last1=Abbott|editor-first1=Lyman|editor-last2=Mabie|editor-first2=H. W.|title=An American Queen|work=The Outlook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O74GAQAAIAAJ|volume=116|number=5|date=May 30, 1917|location=New York|oclc=5361126|pages=177–178|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423235255/https://books.google.com/books?id=O74GAQAAIAAJ|archivedate=April 23, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Elima Keiki Hawaii i Make|newspaper=Ke Aloha Aina|location=Honolulu|date=April 6, 1917|volume=XXII|issue=14|page=1|url=http://nupepa.org/gsdl2.5/cgi-bin/nupepa?e=d-0nupepa--00-0-0--010---4----text-prev--0-1l--1haw-Zz-1--en-20-about--20-00031-0000utfZz-8-00-0003-1-0000utfZz-8-00&a=d&cl=CL1.33.23&d=HASH016126140b897fd6173f88af&gg=prev|accessdate=September 26, 2016}} Subsequent historians have disputed the true meaning of her act; Neil Thomas Proto argued that "[h]er gesture that day was intended to reflect the dignity with which she still held the right of her people to choose their own fate long after she was gone".{{harvnb|Proto|2009|p=207}} By the end of that summer, the ''[[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]]'' reported that she was too frail to hold her birthday reception for the public, an annual tradition dating back to the days of the monarchy.{{cite news|title=Queen Not to Hold Reception|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=August 29, 1917|at=p. 10, col. 5|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-08-29/ed-1/seq-10/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109075344/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-08-29/ed-1/seq-10/|archivedate=November 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=The Queen's Birthday|newspaper=The Daily Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=September 3, 1892|at=Image 3, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1892-09-03/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119064915/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82016412/1892-09-03/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=November 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}} As one of her last public appearances in September, she officially became a member of the [[American Red Cross]].{{cite news|title=Liliuokalani Becomes a Red Cross Member as Whistles Signify 8000 Mark is Reached|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=September 29, 1917|at=p. 2, col. 2–5|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-09-29/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171109075407/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-09-29/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 9, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Following several months of deteriorating health that left her without the use of her lower limbs, as well as a diminished mental capacity rendering her incapable of recognizing her own house, her inner circle of friends and caregivers sat vigil for the last two weeks of her life knowing the end was near. In accordance with Hawaiian tradition, the royal ''[[kāhili]]'' fanned her as she lay in bed. On the morning of November 11, Liliʻuokalani died at the age of seventy-nine at her residence at Washington Place.{{harvnb|Hodges|1918|pp=35–37}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|p=396}} [[File:Liliʻuokalani Burial Vault.jpg|thumb|200px|Burial Vault of Queen Liliʻuokalani at the Royal Mausoleum of Hawaii]] The bells of [[Cathedral Church of Saint Andrew (Honolulu)|Saint Andrew Cathedral]] and [[Kawaiahaʻo Church]] announced her death, tolling 79 times to signify her age. In keeping with Hawaiian tradition regarding deceased royalty, her body was not removed from her home until nearly midnight.{{cite news|title=Death Comes to Hawaii's Queen in Calm of Sabbath Morning|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=November 12, 1917|at=p. 2 headline|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-11-12/ed-1/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108164527/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-11-12/ed-1/seq-2/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Her body lay in state at Kawaiahaʻo Church for public viewing, after which she received a [[Death and state funeral of Liliuokalani|state funeral]] in the throne room of [[Iolani Palace]], on November 18. Composer [[Charles E. King]] led a youth choir in "Aloha ʻOe" as her [[catafalque]] was moved from the palace up Nuuanu Avenue with 1200-foot ropes pulled by 200 people, for entombment with her family members in the Kalākaua Crypt at the [[Royal Mausoleum of Hawaii|Royal Mausoleum of Mauna ʻAla]]. The song was picked up by the procession participants and the crowds of people along the route.{{harvnb|Askman|2015|pp=91–93}}; {{harvnb|Allen|1982|pp=396–400}}; {{harvnb|Thrum|1918|pages=102–109}}; {{harvnb|Parker|2008|p=36}}; {{cite news|title=Funeral is Held in the Throne Room|newspaper=The Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|date=November 20, 1917|at=p. 3, col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1917-11-20/ed-1/seq-3/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920142125/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1917-11-20/ed-1/seq-3/|archivedate=September 20, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=Martial Pomp and Hawaiian Picturequeness in Funeral Cortege|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=November 19, 1917|at=p. 3 headline|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-11-19/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930084239/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-11-19/ed-1/seq-5/|archivedate=September 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title="Aloha ʻOe" of Queen's Own Song Goes With Her Into Resting-Place|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|location=Honolulu|date=November 19, 1917|at=p. 9 headline|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-11-19/ed-1/seq-9/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|8=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170228124831/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1917-11-19/ed-1/seq-9/|archivedate=February 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Films were taken of the funeral procession and later stored at [[ʻĀinahau]], the former residence of her sister and niece. A fire on August 1, 1921, destroyed the home and all its contents, including the footage of the Queen's funeral.{{harvnb|Allen|1982|p=399}}; {{cite news|last=Gessler|first=Clifford F.|title=Honolulu Letter|newspaper=The Step Ladder|location=Chicago|date=October 1921|volume=III|issue=5|p=76–77|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NKM4AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA76|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423235838/https://books.google.com/books?id=NKM4AQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA76|archivedate=April 23, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite news|title=ON THE OTHER ISLANDS: Ainahau Burns|2=|newspaper=The Maui News|location=Wailuku|date=August 5, 1921|at=p. 8, col. 4|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014689/1921-08-05/ed-1/seq-8/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170528152225/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014689/1921-08-05/ed-1/seq-8/|archivedate=May 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} == Religious beliefs == Educated by American Protestant missionaries from a young age, Liliʻuokalani became a devout Christian and adherent to the principles of Christianity. These missionaries were largely of [[Congregationalist]] and [[Presbyterian]] extractions, subscribing to [[Calvinist]] theology, and Liliʻuokalani considered herself a "regular attendant on the Presbyterian worship".{{sfnm|1a1=Allen|1y=1982|1pp=69|2a1=Merry|2y=2000|2p=63|3a1=Liliuokalani|3y=1898|3p=269}} She was the first member of the royal family to consistently and regularly attend service at Kawaiahaʻo Church since King Kamehameha IV converted to [[Anglicanism]]. On Sundays, she played the organ and led the choir at Kawaiahaʻo. She also regularly attended service at [[Kaumakapili Church]] and held a special interest in the [[Liliuokalani Protestant Church|Liliʻuokalani Protestant Church]], to which she donated the Queen Liliʻuokalani Clock in 1892.{{sfnm|1a1=Kuykendall|1y=1967|1p=479|2a1=Allen|2y=1982|2pp=76–77}} Historian Helena G. Allen noted that Liliʻuokalani and Kalākaua "believed all religions had their 'rights' and were entitled to equal treatment and opportunities". Throughout her life, Liliʻuokalani showed a broad interest in the different Christian faiths including [[Catholicism]], [[Mormonism]], [[Episcopalianism]] and other [[Protestant]] denominations.{{sfn|Allen|1982|page=241}} In 1896, she became a regular member of the Hawaiian Congregation at [[Cathedral Church of Saint Andrew (Honolulu)|St. Andrew's Cathedral]] associated with the Reformed Catholic (Anglican/Episcopal) Church of Hawaii, which King Kamehameha IV and Queen Emma had founded.{{sfn|Kuykendall|1967|page=479}} During the overthrow and her imprisonment, Bishop [[Alfred Willis]] of St. Andrew's Cathedral had openly supported the Queen while Reverend [[Henry Hodges Parker]] of Kawaiahaʻo had supported her opponents.{{sfnm|1a1=Kuykendall|1y=1967|1p=479|2a1=Garrett|2y=1992|2p=238}} Bishop Willis visited and wrote to her during her imprisonment and sent her a copy of the [[Book of Common Prayer]].{{sfn|Allen|1982|page=346}} Shortly after her release on parole, the former queen was baptized and confirmed by Bishop Willis on May 18, 1896, in a private ceremony in the presence of the sisters of St. Andrew's Priory.{{cite news|title=Join St. Andrew's – Ex-queen Liliuokalani Confirmed by Bishop Willis|newspaper=Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|publisher=|date=May 19, 1896|volume=XXXI|issue=40|at=p. 4, col. 6|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1896-05-19/ed-1/seq-4/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171001035930/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1896-05-19/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=October 1, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In her memoir, Liliʻuokalani stated:
That first night of my imprisonment was the longest night I have ever passed in my life; it seemed as though the dawn of day would never come. I found in my bag a small Book of Common Prayer according to the ritual of the Episcopal Church. It was a great comfort to me, and before retiring to rest Mrs. Clark and I spent a few minutes in the devotions appropriate to the evening. Here, perhaps, I may say, that although I had been a regular attendant on the Presbyterian worship since my childhood, a constant contributor to all the missionary societies, and had helped to build their churches and ornament the walls, giving my time and my musical ability freely to make their meetings attractive to my people, yet none of these pious church members or clergymen remembered me in my prison. To this (Christian ?) conduct I contrast that of the Anglican bishop, Rt. Rev. Alfred Willis, who visited me from time to time in my house, and in whose church I have since been confirmed as a communicant. But he was not allowed to see me at the palace.{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|page=269}}
She traveled to Utah in 1901 for a visit with [[President of the Church (LDS Church)|Mormon president]] [[Joseph F. Smith]], a former missionary to the Hawaiian Island. There she joined in services at the [[Salt Lake Tabernacle]], and was feted at a [[Beehive House]] reception, attended by many [[expatriate]] Native Hawaiians.{{cite news|title=Queen at Salt Lake|newspaper=The Pacific Commercial Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=December 11, 1900|volume=XXXIV|issue=6037|at=Image 9, col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1901-12-11/ed-1/seq-9/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010104948/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047084/1901-12-11/ed-1/seq-9/|archivedate=October 10, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In 1906, she was baptized into [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] by Elder Abraham Kaleimahoe Fernandez.{{cite journal|last=Walker|first=Isaiah|title=Abraham Kaleimahoe Fernandez: A Hawaiian Saint and Royalist, 1857–1915|journal=Mormon Pacific Historical Society Proceedings, 28th Annual Conference|volume=28|issue=|date=March 17, 2007|location=Kaneohe, Hawaii|url=http://scholarsarchive.byu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1217&context=mphs|accessdate=September 29, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161003164625/http://scholarsarchive.byu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1217&context=mphs|archivedate=October 3, 2016|df=mdy-all}} However, her interest in Mormonism later waned.{{sfn|Britsch|1986|pages=137–138}} The Queen was also remembered for her support of [[Buddhist]] and [[Shinto]] priests in Hawaii and became one of the first Native Hawaiians to attend a [[Buddha's Birthday#Japan|Buddha's Birthday]] celebration of May 19, 1901, at the [[Honpa Hongwanji Mission of Hawaii|Honwangji mission]]. Her attendance in the celebration helped Buddhism and Shintoism gain acceptance into Hawaiian society and prevented the possible banning of the two religions by the Territorial government. Her presence was also widely reported in Chinese and Japanese newspapers throughout the world, and earned her the respect of many Japanese people both in Hawaii and in Japan itself.{{sfn|Koda|2006|page=237}} == Compositions == [[File:Aloha oe song 01.png|thumb|200px|right|Cover of [[Aloha ʻOe]], 1890 {{audio|Aloha oe song midi.mid|Play}}]] {{Main|List of compositions and works by Liliuokalani}} Liliʻuokalani was an accomplished author and songwriter. Her book ''Hawaiʻi's Story by Hawaiʻi's Queen'' gave her view of the history of her country and her overthrow. She is said to have played guitar, piano, [[organ (music)|organ]], [[ukulele|ʻukulele]] and [[zither]], and also sang alto, performing Hawaiian and English sacred and secular music.{{cite book|title=Hawaii Magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eW7xAAAAMAAJ|year=2004|publisher=Fancy Publications|location=Irvine, CA|oclc=27971891|pages=56, 58|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113013956/https://books.google.com/books?id=eW7xAAAAMAAJ|archivedate=January 13, 2018|df=mdy-all}}{{sfn|Garraty|Carnes|American Council of Learned Societies|1999|pages=664–665}} In her memoirs she wrote: {{quote |To compose was as natural to me as to breathe; and this gift of nature, never having been suffered to fall into disuse, remains a source of the greatest consolation to this day.[…] Hours of which it is not yet in place to speak, which I might have found long and lonely, passed quickly and cheerfully by, occupied and soothed by the expression of my thoughts in music.{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|page=31}}}} Liliʻuokalani helped preserve key elements of Hawaiʻi's traditional poetics while mixing in Western harmonies brought by the missionaries. A compilation of her works, titled ''The Queen's Songbook'', was published in 1999 by the Queen Liliʻuokalani Trust.{{sfn|Silva|2004|page=201}} Liliʻuokalani used her musical compositions as a way to express her feelings for her people, her country, and what was happening in the political realm in Hawaiʻi.{{cite web|last=Ducat|first=Vivian|title=Hawaii's Last Queen|work=American Experience|publisher=PBS|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/hawaii/program.html|accessdate=October 11, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110828041232/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/hawaii/program.html|archivedate=August 28, 2011|df=mdy-all}} One example of the way her music reflected her political views is her translation of the [[Kumulipo]], the Hawaiian creation chant. While under house arrest, Liliʻuokalani feared she would never leave the palace alive, so she translated the Kumulipo in hopes that the history and culture of her people would never be lost.{{cite web|title=Her History|publisher=Queen Liliʻuokalani Trust|url=http://onipaa.org/pages/her-history/|accessdate=October 12, 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225233200/http://onipaa.org/pages/her-history|archivedate=December 25, 2014|df=mdy-all}} The ancient chants record her family's genealogy back to the origin story of Hawaiʻi.{{sfn|Beckwith|1972|page=xiv}} After Liliʻuokalani was imprisoned in the ʻIolani Palace, she was denied literature and newspapers, essentially cutting her off from her people, but she continued to compose music with paper and pencil while she was in confinement.{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=289–90}} Another of her compositions was "Aloha ʻOe", a song she had written previously and transcribed during her confinement. In her writings, she says, "At first I had no instrument, and had to transcribe the notes by voice alone; but I found, notwithstanding disadvantages, great consolation in composing, and transcribed a number of songs. Three found their way from my prison to the city of Chicago, where they were printed, among them the 'Aloha ʻOe' or 'Farewell to Thee', which became a very popular song."{{sfn|Liliuokalani|1898|pages=289–90}} Originally written as a lover's good-bye, the song came to be regarded as a symbol of, and lament for, the loss of her country. Today, it is one of the most recognizable Hawaiian songs. == Legacy == Captain Julius A. Palmer Jr. of Massachusetts was her friend for three decades, and became her spokesperson when she was in residence at Boston and Washington D.C., protesting the annexation of Hawaiʻi. In the nation's capital, he estimated that she had 5,000 visitors. When asked by an interviewer, "What are her most distinctive personal graces?", Palmer replied, "Above everything else she displayed a disposition of the most Christian forgiveness."{{cite news|title=Julius A. Palmer's Story|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1897-09-29/ed-1/seq-1/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|work=The Independent (reprinted from [[The Boston Globe]])|date=September 29, 1897|at=Image 4, col. 3|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108162842/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047097/1897-09-29/ed-1/seq-1/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In covering her death and funeral, the mainstream newspapers in Hawaii that had supported the overthrow and annexation recognized that she had been held in great esteem around the world.{{sfn|Askman|2015}} In March 2016, ''[[Hawaiʻi Magazine]]'' listed Liliʻuokalani as one of the most influential women in Hawaiian history.{{cite news|last=Dekneef|first=Matthew|title=14 extraordinary women in Hawaii history everyone should know|newspaper=Hawaiʻi Magazine|location=Honolulu|date=March 9, 2016|url=http://www.hawaiimagazine.com/incredible-hawaii-women-in-history|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170601052657/http://www.hawaiimagazine.com/incredible-hawaii-women-in-history|archivedate=June 1, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The Queen Liliʻuokalani Trust was established on December 2, 1909, for the care of orphaned and destitute children in Hawaii. Effective upon her death, the proceeds of her estate, with the exception of twelve individual inheritances specified therein, were to be used for the Trust.{{cite web|title=Queen Liliʻuokalani Deed of Trust|publisher=Queen Liliʻuokalani Trust|url=http://onipaa.org/pages/her-deed-of-trust|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006101611/http://www.onipaa.org/pages/her-deed-of-trust|archivedate=October 6, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The largest of these hereditary estates were willed to her ''hānai'' sons and their heirs: John ʻAimoku Dominis would receive Washington Place while Joseph Kaiponohea ʻAeʻa would receive Kealohilani, her residence at Waikiki. Both men predeceased the Queen.{{cite news|title=J. Aimoku Dominis, Ward of Queen, Succumbs To Illness|newspaper=Hawaiian Gazette|location=Honolulu|date=July 10, 1917|at=p. 5, col. 6|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1917-07-10/ed-1/seq-5/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108164445/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83025121/1917-07-10/ed-1/seq-5/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=Prominent Hawaiian Is Laid To Rest|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=November 16, 1914|at=p. 2, col. 2|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1914-11-16/ed-2/seq-2/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171108164447/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014682/1914-11-16/ed-2/seq-2/|archivedate=November 8, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Before and after her death, lawsuits were filed to overturn her will establishing the Trust. One notable litigant was Prince [[Jonah Kūhiō Kalanianaʻole]], the nephew of her brother Kalākaua and his wife Kapiʻolani and Liliʻuokalani's second cousin, who brought a suit against the Trust on November 30, 1915, questioning the Queen's competency in executing the will and attempting to break the Trust. These lawsuits were resolved in 1923 and the will went into probate.{{cite news|last=|first=|title=The Queen's Estate: First of Two Parts|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=May 17, 2009|volume=|issue=|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/content/20090517_The_Queens_estate|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022030327/http://archives.starbulletin.com/content/20090517_The_Queens_estate|archivedate=October 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|last=|first=|title=The Queen's Estate: Last of Two Parts|newspaper=Honolulu Star-Bulletin|date=May 18, 2009|volume=|issue=|url=http://archives.starbulletin.com/content/20090518_The_Queens_estate|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161022030819/http://archives.starbulletin.com/content/20090518_The_Queens_estate|archivedate=October 22, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The Queen Liliʻuokalani Children's Center was created by the Trust.{{cite web|title=The Children's Center|url=http://onipaa.org/pages/the-children-s-center|publisher=Queen Liliʻuokalani Trust|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008031303/http://onipaa.org/pages/the-children-s-center|archivedate=October 8, 2016|df=mdy-all}}{{sfn|Lowe|1994|page=91–93}} Liliʻuokalani and her siblings are recognized by the [[Hawaiian Music Hall of Fame]] as the ''Na Lani ʻEhā'' (''The Heavenly Four'') for their patronage and enrichment of Hawaii's musical culture and history.{{cite web|title=About Us: Patron of Hawaiian Music Culture|publisher=Hawaiian Music Hall of Fame|url=http://www.hmhof.org/about-us|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171022182645/http://www.hmhof.org/about-us|archivedate=October 22, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Marjorie J.|title=Contributions of royal family recognized|newspaper=The Honolulu Advertiser|location=Honolulu|date=September 8, 1995|volume=|issue=|page=17|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/265527025/|via=Newspapers.com|subscription=yes|accessdate=July 4, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180730202724/https://www.newspapers.com/image/265527025/|archive-date=July 30, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} In 2007, ''[[Honolulu (magazine)|Honolulu]]'' magazine rated "Aloha ʻOe" as the greatest song in the history of Hawaiian music.{{cite journal|last1=Bolante|first1=Ronna|last2=Keany|first2=Michael|title=50 Greatest Songs of Hawaii|magazine=[[Honolulu (magazine)|Honolulu]]|location=Honolulu|date=June 1, 2007|url=http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/June-2007/50-Greatest-Songs-of-Hawai-8217i/|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170213231635/http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Magazine/June-2007/50-Greatest-Songs-of-Hawai-8217i/|archivedate=February 13, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Songwriter Charles E. King, known as the composer of "[[Hawaiian Wedding Song|Ke Kali Nei Au]]", was tutored in music by her.{{cite web|title=Charles E. King|publisher=Hawaiian Music Hall of Fame|url=http://www.digitaldna.co.jp/hawaiianmusichalloffame/hmhof/honorees/1995/king.html|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170318022921/http://www.digitaldna.co.jp/hawaiianmusichalloffame/hmhof/honorees/1995/king.html|archivedate=March 18, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Entertainer [[Bina Mossman]] led the Bina Mossman Glee Club that rehearsed regularly at Washington Place, while Liliʻuokalani helped them with pronunciation of the Hawaiian language. At the queen's funeral, the glee club was part of the [[kahili]] bearers who stood watch over the coffin for two hours at a time, waving the kahilis and singing Liliʻuokalani's compositions.{{harvnb|Mossman|1979|pages=}}{{harvnb|Thrum|1918|pages=}} The annual Queen Liliʻuokalani Outrigger Canoe Race, which follows an 18-mile course from Kailua Bay to Honaunau Bay, was organized in 1972 as an endurance training course for men, in preparation for the traditional Molokaʻi to Oʻahu canoe races. Women canoe teams were added in 1974. The race is held over [[Labor Day Weekend]] each year to coincide with Liliʻuokalani's birthday on September 2.{{cite news|last1=Barnes|first1=Susan B.|title=Alohas, sisterhood and grit: the Queen Liliʻuokalani Long Distance Canoe Race|url=http://www.espn.com/espnw/sports/article/20746656/queen-liliuokalani-long-distance-canoe-race|accessdate=October 15, 2017|work=espnW|date=September 18, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930175712/http://www.espn.com/espnw/sports/article/20746656/queen-liliuokalani-long-distance-canoe-race|archivedate=September 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{cite web|last1=Club|first1=Kai Opua Canoe|title=Queen Liliʻuokalani Canoe Race – World's Largest Outrigger Canoe Race|url=https://www.qlcanoerace.com/ql-race-history.asp|publisher=Kai 'Opua Canoe Club|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930180233/https://www.qlcanoerace.com/ql-race-history.asp|archivedate=September 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In the 2001 naming of the "Queen Liliʻuokalani Center for Studies Services", on the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa]] campus, the Board of Regents noted, "As the last Hawaiian monarch, Queen Liliʻuokalani symbolizes an important link to traditional Hawaiian culture and society. Her influence is well understood, widely respected and has been a strong motivating factor in the widespread emergence of Hawaiian culture and the values embodied in it."{{cite web|author=University of Hawaii at Manoa Board of Regents|title=Minutes of the Regular Meeting of the Board of Regents for October 19, 2001|date=October 19, 2001|url=http://www.hawaii.edu/offices/bor/regular/minute/20011019.regular.html|publisher=University of Hawaii|location=Honolulu|accessdate=October 15, 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011075337/http://www.hawaii.edu/offices/bor/regular/minute/20011019.regular.html|archivedate=October 11, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Numerous hula events are held to honor her memory, including the Queen Liliʻuokalani Keiki Hula Competition Honolulu, organized in 1976.{{cite web|title=About Keiki Hula|url=http://keikihula.org/about.html|publisher=Kalihi-Palama Culture & Arts Society, Inc.|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930175933/http://keikihula.org/about.html|archivedate=September 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|title=Sinclair Library: Streaming Hawaiian Videos: Keiki Hula|url=http://guides.library.manoa.hawaii.edu/streaming-hawaiian-videos/keiki|publisher=University of Hawaii at Manoa Library|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005111316/http://guides.library.manoa.hawaii.edu/streaming-hawaiian-videos/keiki|archivedate=October 5, 2016|df=mdy-all}} The County of Hawaii holds an annual He Hali'a Aloha no Lili'uokalani Festival, Queen's Birthday Celebration at [[Liliʻuokalani Park and Gardens]] in Hilo, in partnership with the Queen Lili'uokalani Trust. The event begins with several hundred dancers showered by 50,000 orchid blossoms.{{cite web|title=2017 Queen Lili’uokalani Festival set for Saturday, September 9 in Hilo|url=http://hawaiicountymayor.com/2017/08/24/2017-queen-liliuokalani-festival-set-for-saturday-september-9-in-hilo/|website=Office of Mayor Harry Kim|publisher=County of Hawaii|accessdate=October 15, 2017|date=August 24, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170917012238/http://hawaiicountymayor.com/2017/08/24/2017-queen-liliuokalani-festival-set-for-saturday-september-9-in-hilo/|archivedate=September 17, 2017|df=mdy-all}} == Titles, styles and arms == === Titles and styles === *'''1838 – September 16, 1862''': ''[[The Honorable]] Miss'' Lydia Kamakaʻeha Pākī{{cite news|title=The Court|newspaper=The Polynesian|location=Honolulu|date=December 5, 1857|volume=XIV|issue=31|at=p. 244, col. 1|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1857-12-05/ed-1/seq-4|accessdate=October 15, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119064414/http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015408/1857-12-05/ed-1/seq-4/|archivedate=November 19, 2017|df=mdy-all}}; {{refimprove|date=December 2016}} A '''literary festival''', also known as a '''book festival''' or '''writers' festival''', is a regular gathering of [[writer]]s and readers, typically on an annual basis in a particular city. A literary festival usually features a variety of presentations and readings by authors, as well as other events, delivered over a period of several days, with the primary objectives of promoting the authors' books and fostering a love of literature and writing.
[[List of writers' conferences|Writers' conferences]] are sometimes designed to provide an intellectual and academic focus for groups of writers without the involvement of the general public.
There are many literary festivals held around the world. A non-exhaustive list is set out below, including dates when a festival is usually held (where available).

[[File:United Kingdom EU referendum 2016 area results (Greater London).svg|thumb|right|261px|Greater London, showing majority voting in the [[Brexit referendum]] by area {{legend|#0069b5|Leave}} {{legend|#ffc010|Remain}}]] {{United Kingdom in the European Union}} {{use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} '''London independence''', sometimes shortened to '''Londependence''',{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/live/eu-referendum/londependence/|title=‘Londependence’ May Be a Dream, but More Autonomy for the City Is Not|date= 28 June 2016 |publisher=The New York Times}} refers to a belief favouring full-fledged independence for [[Greater London|London]] as a [[city-state]] separate from the [[United Kingdom]]. ==Movement== London's status within the United Kingdom has been debated for several years, with some calls for increased autonomy,{{cite web|url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/europpblog/2016/01/30/the-uk-needs-a-devolved-government-for-london/|title=The UK needs a devolved government for London|date=30 January 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://theconversation.com/london-after-brexit-independence-a-non-starter-but-special-status-could-protect-global-position-61609|title=London after Brexit: independence a non-starter but special status could protect global position|first=Richard G|last=Smith|publisher=}} Supporters have frequently cited Greater London's population of over 8 million people, its economic size, its global role, its diverse population and its unique challenges compared to the rest of [[England]] as reasons for greater autonomy. The idea of London becoming a city-state was discussed from the 1990s, and resurfaced during the [[Scottish independence referendum, 2014|Scottish independence referendum of 2014]]. The movement for either increased autonomy or full sovereignty received a boost following the [[UK EU referendum]] in 2016, during which the UK as a whole voted to leave the European Union (at 52% leave), although the majority of London voted for the UK to remain in the EU (60% remain). This led to 180,000 Londoners petitioning [[Sadiq Khan]], [[Mayor of London]] online to seek London's independence from the UK so it could remain part of the EU. Supporters cite London's status as a "[[world city]]" and its demographic and economic differences from the rest of the United Kingdom, and argue that it should become a city-state based on the model of [[Singapore]], while remaining an EU member state.{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/story/1716977/second-scotland-referendum-highly-likely|title=Second Scotland Referendum 'Highly Likely'}}{{cite web|url=http://www.london24.com/news/politics/londoners_call_for_independence_from_uk_1_4591200|title=Londoners call for independence from UK|first=Zoah|last=Hedges-Stocks|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160625122929/http://www.london24.com/news/politics/londoners_call_for_independence_from_uk_1_4591200|archivedate=25 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/brexit-latest-london-independence-time-to-leave-uk-eu-referendum-sadiq-khan-boris-johnson-a7100601.html|title=It's time for London to leave the UK|date=24 June 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/london/wouldnt-you-prefer-to-be-president-sadiq-thousands-back-campaign-for-sadiq-khan-to-declare-londons-a3280141.html|title=Thousands call on Sadiq Khan to declare London's independence|date=24 June 2016}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/londependence-petition-calls-for-london-to-join-the-eu-on-its-own-a7101006.html|title='Londependence' petition calls for London to join the EU on its own|date=24 June 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2016/06/24/londoners-want-their-own-independence-after-brexit-result/|title=Londoners want their own independence after Brexit result}}{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/06/24/70000-sign-petition-for-london-to-become-independent-and-rejoin-the-eu-5965541/|title=70,000 sign petition for London to become independent and rejoin the EU|first=Nicole Morley for|last=Metro.co.uk|date=24 June 2016}} [[Spencer Livermore]] of the Labour Party said that London's independence "should be a goal", arguing that a London city-state would have twice the GDP of Singapore.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/eu-referendum-london-independence_uk_576d4c57e4b0d257114993a2|title=London Independence Goes Beyond A Twitter Joke With Politicians Seriously Discussing It|date=24 June 2016}} Journalist [[Tony Travers]] argued that Khan would be "well within his rights to tell the government London didn't vote for Brexit and that City Hall now viewed the government as dysfunctional." Analyst Kevin Doran said that London becoming an independent state is not just possible, but inevitable "within 20 to 30 years' time."{{cite web|url=http://www.theweek.co.uk/73896/london-independence-could-the-capital-break-away-from-the-uk|title=London independence: Could the capital break away from the UK?|publisher=}} After the EU referendum vote, Peter John, the Labour Party leader of the [[London Borough of Southwark]] stated it would be a "legitimate question" for London to consider its future in the United Kingdom and the European Union. Southwark had voted 72% in favour of remaining in the EU. John also said "London would be the 15th largest EU state, bigger than Austria, Denmark and Ireland and our values are in line with Europe – outward looking, confident of our place in the world, enriched by our diversity and stronger working together with our friends and neighbours than we are alone."{{cite news|url=http://www.southwarknews.co.uk/news/southwark-council-leader-backs-calls-london-consider-independence-uk-eu-referendum-result/|title=Southwark Council Leader backs calls for London to consider independence from UK after EU Referendum result|author=Alex Yeates|date=24 June 2016 | newspaper=[[Southwark News]] |accessdate=26 June 2016}} ==Public opinion== Two opinion polls have been carried out by the polling company [[YouGov]] on Londoners' preferred constitutional status. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: center; line-height: 14px; font-size: 95%;" |- ! style="width: 120px;" ! | Date(s)
conducted !! style="width: 300px;" |Polling organisation/client!! class="unsortable" style="width: 65px;" | Sample size!! class="unsortable" style="background: rgb(0, 129, 66); width: 100px; color: white;" | Status Quo (London Assembly)!! class="unsortable" style="background: orange; width: 100px; color: white;" |London Parliament!! class="unsortable" style="background: rgb(220, 36, 31); width: 90px; color: white;" |Abolish the Assembly!! class="unsortable" style="background: #004281; width: 90px; color: white;" |London Independence!! class="unsortable" style="background: gray; width: 90px; color: white;" | Undecided |- | data-sort-value="2016-07-06" | 1–6 July 2016 || [https://d25d2506sfb94s.cloudfront.net/cumulus_uploads/document/4s7vvulwm6/EveningStandardResults_London_SadiqMayor_EURef_Housing_Independence_Website.pdf YouGov/Evening Standard] || 1,061 || style="background: rgb(153, 255, 153) " | '''32%''' || 23% || 7% || 11% || 28% |- | data-sort-value="2014-10-08" | 8–13 Oct 2014 || [https://d25d2506sfb94s.cloudfront.net/cumulus_uploads/document/4s7vvulwm6/EveningStandardResults_London_SadiqMayor_EURef_Housing_Independence_Website.pdf YouGov/Evening Standard] || || style="background: rgb(153, 255, 153) | '''30%''' || style="background: #ffd27f;" | '''30%''' || 6% || 5% || 29% |} A different survey of 2,001 people carried out by the firm Censuswide in September 2014 found that 19.9% of Londoners wanted the city to become independent, with support for this being highest among people aged 25–34.{{cite web |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/one-in-five-londoners-want-capital-to-split-from-rest-of-uk-and-become-independent-9722652.html |title='One in five Londoners want the capital to become independent' |last=Moore-Bridger |first=Benedict |date=10 September 2014 |publisher=Evening Standard |access-date=31 March 2017 |quote=19.9 per cent of the 2,001 people surveyed agree[d] it [London] would be better off as its own country.}} ==Criticism== The idea of London independence has been criticised as unrealistic. Brian Groom of the ''[[Financial Times]]'' wrote that "it is ludicrous to think of any nation gladly waving goodbye to its capital", calling the idea of secession a "fantasy".{{cite web |url=https://www.ft.com/content/a97a4f1c-0a8b-11e3-aeab-00144feabdc0 |title=Could London ever be a city-state? |last=Groom |first=Brian |date=26 August 2013 |publisher=Financial Times |access-date=31 March 2017 |quote=This is, of course, fantasy. Unlike Scotland, London has no separatist movement.}} Dr. James Ker-Lindsay, a senior research fellow at the [[London School of Economics]] who specialises in secession movements, stated with regard to a referendum on London Independence that it "seems difficult to see how any government would ever agree to such a vote." He also said if London broke away without permission it would not be able to join the UN.https://www.vice.com/en_au/article/we-asked-an-expert-if-london-could-secede-from-the-uk| ==See also== *[[Scottish independence]] *[[Urban secession]] *[[London Assembly]] *[[City of London Corporation]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016}} {{London history}} [[Category:2016 in London]] [[Category:Separatism in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Greater London]] [[Category:Independence movements]] [[Category:Consequences of the United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016]] [[Category:Politics of London]]

{{lead too short|date=November 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{About|The Costume Institute Gala|Metropolitan Opera Gala information|Met Gala (opera)}} {{good article}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = Met Gala | logo = | image = | caption = | genre = Fundraising gala, costume exhibition | founder_name = [[Eleanor Lambert]] | venue = [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], [[Costume Institute]] | location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | country = United States | frequency = First Monday of May<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/03/fashion/what-is-the-met-gala-and-who-gets-to-go.html|title=What Is the Met Gala, and Who Gets to Go?|first=Vanessa|last=Friedman|date=May 3, 2018|work=New York Times|access-date=August 22, 2018|language=en}}</ref> | years_active = 1948{{ndash}}present<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/when-met-gala-2018-where-12460938|title=What is the Met Gala 2018 theme - and what it means|last=Hardie|first=Beth|date=May 7, 2018|work=[[Mirror (UK)]]|access-date=August 22, 2018}}</ref> | organised = ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' | last = {{Date|2018-05-07|mdy}} | next = {{Date|2019-05-06|mdy}} | website = [http://metmuseum.org/metgala Costume Institute Gala] | footnotes = Gala started in 1946 and the first event was held in 1948.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/what-is-the-met-gala-things-to-know-andre-leon-talley|title=What Is the Met Gala? Everything You Need to Know|first=Maria|last=Ward|work=Vogue| date=May 7, 2018|access-date=August 22, 2018|language=en}}</ref> }} [[File:Image-Metropolitan Museum of Art entrance NYC NY.JPG|thumb|[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vogue.com/13430960/met-gala-history-60-seconds-hamish-bowles/|title=A History of the Met Gala in 60 Seconds, Narrated by Vogue’s Hamish Bowles|last=Borrelli-Persson|first=Laird|website=Vogue|language=en-US|access-date=May 17, 2016}}</ref> where the Met Gala has been held annually since 1972.]] The '''Met Gala''', formally called the '''Costume Institute Gala''' and also known as the '''Met Ball''', is an annual fundraising [[festival|gala]] for the benefit of the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]'s [[Costume Institute]] in [[New York City]]. It marks the grand opening of the Costume Institute's annual fashion exhibit.<ref name="metmuseum.org">{{Cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/about-the-met/curatorial-departments/the-costume-institute|title=The Costume Institute {{!}} The Metropolitan Museum of Art|website=www.metmuseum.org|access-date=May 17, 2016}}</ref> Each year's event celebrates the theme of that year's Costume Institute exhibition, and the exhibition sets the tone for the formal dress of the night, since guests are expected to choose their fashion to match the theme of the exhibit.
== History == The Met Gala was established in 1948 by legendary fashion publicist [[Eleanor Lambert]] as a way to raise money for the newly-founded Costume Institute and mark the opening of its annual exhibit. The first gala was a midnight dinner and tickets were fifty dollars each.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.metmuseum.org/blogs/now-at-the-met/2018/met-gala-costume-institute-benefit-brief-history|title=https://www.metmuseum.org/blogs/now-at-the-met/2018/met-gala-costume-institute-benefit-brief-history|website=www.metmuseum.org|access-date=2018-12-01}}</ref> While Lambert herself dubbed it the "Party of the Year," for the first few decades of its existence the gala was simply one of many annual benefits held for New York charitable institutions. Accordingly, the attendees of the early galas were almost entirely members of New York high society or the fashion industry. From 1948 to 1971, the event was held at venues including the [[Waldorf Astoria New York|Waldorf-Astoria]], [[Central Park]], and [[Rainbow Room]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/gallery/the-met-galas-history-and-decor-throughout-the-years/all|title=A Look Back At The Met Gala's History And Decor Throughout The Years {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-12-01|language=en}}</ref>
When former Vogue editor-in-chief [[Diana Vreeland|Diane Vreeland]] became special consultant to the Costume Institute in 1972, the Gala began to evolve into a more glamorous affair, although one that was still aimed at the societal set.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.townandcountrymag.com/the-scene/parties/a9551568/met-gala-history/|title=The Met Ball Was So Much Better Before All the Celebrities Showed Up|date=2018-05-03|work=Town & Country|access-date=2018-12-01|language=en-US}}</ref> The event started to become more celebrity-oriented with attendees like [[Andy Warhol]], [[Diana Ross]], and [[Cher]] intermixing with the city's elite.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/gallery/the-met-galas-history-and-decor-throughout-the-years/all|title=A Look Back At The Met Gala's History And Decor Throughout The Years {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-12-01|language=en}}</ref> It was during the Vreeland years that the Gala was first held at the Met and that Gala themes were introduced.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/gallery/the-met-galas-history-and-decor-throughout-the-years/all|title=A Look Back At The Met Gala's History And Decor Throughout The Years {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-12-01|language=en}}</ref> By the time Vreeland died in 1989, the Met Gala was well known as a luxurious, blockbuster event and was considered "the jewel in New York City's social crown.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.townandcountrymag.com/the-scene/parties/a9551568/met-gala-history/|title=The Met Ball Was So Much Better Before All the Celebrities Showed Up|date=2018-05-03|work=Town & Country|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.architecturaldigest.com/gallery/the-met-galas-history-and-decor-throughout-the-years/all|title=A Look Back At The Met Gala's History And Decor Throughout The Years {{!}} Architectural Digest|work=Architectural Digest|access-date=2018-12-02|language=en}}</ref>

[[Anna Wintour]], ''Vogue'' [[editor-in-chief]] and a [[chairman|chair]] of the event since 1995 (excluding 1996 and 1998), oversees both the benefit committee and the guest list, with ''Vogue'' staffers helping assemble the list of invitees.<ref name="metmuseum.org"/><ref name=TCBG/> According to Cathy Horyn of ''[[The New York Times]]'', the gathering rivals the West Coast's ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' Oscar Party, which is said to have more "star power" but less fashion panache.<ref name=AP>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/04/fashion/thursdaystyles/05MET.html|title=Anna's Party: Silk, Satin and Pub Grub|accessdate=May 4, 2011|date=May 4, 2006 |work=[[New York Times]]|author=Horyn, Cathy}}</ref> In 2014, the individual tickets cost $30,000 for those outside the official guest list, after prices were raised $10,000 to increase the exclusivity of the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aol.com/article/finance/2017/05/01/met-gala-cost-of-attending-ticket/22063931/|title=You can't afford to go to the Met Gala and you probably wouldn't get in even if you could|first=AOL|last=Staff|publisher=}}</ref><ref name=TCBG>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/shopping/fashion/features/11894/|title=The Charity Ball Game|accessdate=May 4, 2011|date=May 21, 2005 |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Gurfein |first=Laura |url=http://ny.racked.com/archives/2014/04/17/anna_wintour_raised_the_met_ball_ticket_prices_for_exclusivity.php |title=Anna Wintour Raised Met Ball Ticket Prices, Wants 'Exclusivity' – That's a Spicy Met Ball! – Racked NY |publisher=Ny.racked.com |date=April 17, 2014 |accessdate=May 2, 2014}}</ref> The annual guest list includes only 650–700 people.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bourne|first=Leah|url=http://thevivant.com/10-ways-to-get-invited-to-the-met-gala/|title=10 Ways to Get Invited to the Met Gala|work=[[The Vivant]]|accessdate=May 23, 2014|date=April 29, 2013 }}</ref><ref name=TWB/>
==Themes== Each year the event has a theme, and includes a cocktail hour and a formal dinner.<ref>{{cite web|last=Levine |first=Joshua |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052748704893604576200722939264658 |title=Anna Wintour's Brand Anna - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=March 24, 2011 |accessdate=May 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.style.com/peopleparties/parties/scoop/redcarpet-050807MET/|title=Salute to the King: The Haute Monde Descends on the Met to Celebrate Legendary Couturier Paul Poiret|accessdate=May 4, 2011|date=|work=[[Style.com]]|author=Cristobal, Sarah}}</ref> During the cocktail hour, guests arrive to walk on the [[red carpet]], tour the year's special themed exhibition, and be seated before the dinner party that includes entertainment from the preeminent entertainers of the day.<ref name=TWB>{{cite journal|title=The Wild Bunch|journal=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|pages=110–32|date=July 2009}}</ref> The theme not only sets the tone for the annual exhibit, but also for the guests who attempt to dress to uphold the theme of the year, oftentimes causing runs on certain fashion themes among the world's leading fashion retailers.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Revel, Revel|journal=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|pages=116–50|date=July 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2014/05/men-freaking-out-about-what-to-wear-to-met-ball.html|title=Men Are Freaking Out About What to Wear to the Met Ball|accessdate=May 23, 2014|date=May 1, 2014 |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|author=Hyland, Véronique}}</ref> Sometimes, such as in 2013, the theme is a bit befuddling because it does not provide a clear stylistic directive, while at other times, such as 2014 the theme may be far more challenging to one gender than the other.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/tails-of-the-city-7631803|title=Costume Institute Calls for White Tie Dress Code at Gala|accessdate=May 23, 2014|date=April 7, The 2015 Gala and its theme of ''"China: Through the Looking Glass"'' became the subject of a documentary—''[[The First Monday in May]]''' directed by [[Andrew Rossi]] produced by [[Condé Nast]] Entertainment, ''Vogue'', and [[Relativity Studios]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/met-gala-documentary-coming-soon-789353|title=The Met Gala Is Getting the Documentary Treatment|accessdate=May 4, 2015|date=April 16, 2015|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|author=Chan, Stephanie}}</ref> 225 approved photographers, reporters, and social media participants documented the event for the documentary.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/03/style/its-called-the-met-gala-but-its-definitely-anna-wintours-party.html?_r=0|title=It’s Called the Met Gala, but It’s Definitely Anna Wintour’s Party|accessdate=May 4, 2015|date=May 2, 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Friedman, Vanessa}}</ref> All other attendees were forbidden from using social media at the event.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/met-gala-selfies-banned-photos-792765|title=Met Gala: No Selfies Allowed|accessdate=May 4, 2015|date=May 1, 2015|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|author=Chan, Stephanie}}</ref> Guests received notices about the restriction of [[selfie]]s and social media inside the gala.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.etonline.com/fashion/163785_met_gala_bans_selfies/|title=Selfies Banned Inside Met Gala?!|work=Entertainment Tonight|access-date=May 5, 2017|language=en}}</ref> The no-selfie ordinance was extended to the following editions of the Met Gala.
